headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone and Welcome to the Netflix Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. [Operator Instructions] At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I will turn the call over to Deborah Crawford, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please
componenttext: Good day, everyone and Welcome to the Netflix Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. [Operator Instructions] At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I will turn the call over to Deborah Crawford, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. We announced our financial results for the fourth quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific time today. The shareholder letter and the Q4 financial results an
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. We announced our financial results for the fourth quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific time today. The shareholder letter and the Q4 financial results and the webcast of this Q&A session are all available at the company's Investor Relations website at ir.netflix.com. 
As is our standard practice, this call will consist solely of Q&A and we are going to conduct the Q&A via e-mail. Please e-mail your questions to IR@netflix.com. We may make forward-looking statements during this call regarding the company's future performance. Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to risks and uncertainties related to the business. A detailed discussion of such risks and uncertainties is contained in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the Commission on February 22, 2010. A rebroadcast of this Q&A session will be available at the Netflix website after 6:00 p.m. Pacific time today. Before we begin the Q&A, I'd like to turn the call over to Reed.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Deborah. I'd just like to acknowledge that Darren McCarthy has been our CFO and my partner for the last 11 years and there's no way we would've gotten to 20 million subscribers as fast as we did without his incredible work. And we are thrilled to
componenttext: Thanks, Deborah. I'd just like to acknowledge that Darren McCarthy has been our CFO and my partner for the last 11 years and there's no way we would've gotten to 20 million subscribers as fast as we did without his incredible work. And we are thrilled to be able to introduce to you David Wells, who is our new CFO.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Reed. This is David. I'm glad to be joining on the earnings call this afternoon. I've got quite a legacy to follow. I've been part of the Netflix team for seven years and in the background of this call for many of those years. So I look for
componenttext: Great. Thanks, Reed. This is David. I'm glad to be joining on the earnings call this afternoon. I've got quite a legacy to follow. I've been part of the Netflix team for seven years and in the background of this call for many of those years. So I look forward to speaking to many of you in the coming weeks. But I know that you're here for Q&A, so let's get to questions.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The first question is from Youssef Squali of Jefferies and Company. How should we think about overall content spend in 2011 versus 2010 in terms of international and domestic digital rights?
componenttext: The first question is from Youssef Squali of Jefferies and Company. How should we think about overall content spend in 2011 versus 2010 in terms of international and domestic digital rights?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Youssef, I can actually take that. This is David. I think you should mostly think of it as domestic. If you think about the guidance that we gave for Q1 and you scale that for Q2 and when you think about the $50 million on the operating loss we talked abo
componenttext: Youssef, I can actually take that. This is David. I think you should mostly think of it as domestic. If you think about the guidance that we gave for Q1 and you scale that for Q2 and when you think about the $50 million on the operating loss we talked about in Q3 and four, it's not hard to get to a position where most of that spend is domestic.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Arthur Rhodes of Broadpoint Capital Management. Please elaborate on your decision to reduce focus on churn. Even though net additions are ultimately the important statistics, I would've thought that managing churn would be a grea
componenttext: The next question is from Arthur Rhodes of Broadpoint Capital Management. Please elaborate on your decision to reduce focus on churn. Even though net additions are ultimately the important statistics, I would've thought that managing churn would be a great way to make sure you are satisfying your customers.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's Reed here. I guess you say, you don't really manage churn. You manage satisfaction. And then from higher satisfaction comes more word-of-mouth, driving SAC down and new starts up and churn down. And what I come to realize over the years is that net a
componenttext: It's Reed here. I guess you say, you don't really manage churn. You manage satisfaction. And then from higher satisfaction comes more word-of-mouth, driving SAC down and new starts up and churn down. And what I come to realize over the years is that net adds is really the best indicator of that. And this evolution in our part reflects an internal evolution over the past couple of years where I find myself not particularly paying attention to churn in fact much more than net adds which again is the best indicator of satisfaction. And so that's the underlying reason for the evolution.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Heath Terry at Canaccord Genuity. How do marketing deals like the Netflix on remote control compared to your existing subscriber acquisition cost levels?
componenttext: The next question is from Heath Terry at Canaccord Genuity. How do marketing deals like the Netflix on remote control compared to your existing subscriber acquisition cost levels?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Heath, we don't know for sure yet because I guess we would say, we don't know the effectiveness of the buttons. It feels like a great option and once they are in the market, which should be in the middle of this year and then more later in the year, we'll
componenttext: Heath, we don't know for sure yet because I guess we would say, we don't know the effectiveness of the buttons. It feels like a great option and once they are in the market, which should be in the middle of this year and then more later in the year, we'll be able to study really how much consumers view them. So we are optimistic on it. We think it's a great direction but we don't have any hard evidence yet and we won't probably for a year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Second question from Heath. If the improving market for online advertising impacting your online SAC level?
componenttext: Second question from Heath. If the improving market for online advertising impacting your online SAC level?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Not substantially, Heath. It's been pretty steady for us. The good thing that's improved SAC is that we didn't spend that much on marketing in the quarter because it was earning so much in streaming. And when you spend less on marketing, you can think of
componenttext: Not substantially, Heath. It's been pretty steady for us. The good thing that's improved SAC is that we didn't spend that much on marketing in the quarter because it was earning so much in streaming. And when you spend less on marketing, you can think of it skimming the market or you can think of it as we get the flow over from the prior quarters kind of brand build up carries us. And when we go into Q1, we'll spend a little more in marketing, in fact it'll be a little higher. So it's generally in the right direction but not as low as it was in Q4.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next set of questions are coming from Mark Mahaney at Citi Investment Research. First question, what can you disclose about the overall usage patterns of streaming only or streaming mostly subscribers versus your DVD rentals subscribers do they end up
componenttext: The next set of questions are coming from Mark Mahaney at Citi Investment Research. First question, what can you disclose about the overall usage patterns of streaming only or streaming mostly subscribers versus your DVD rentals subscribers do they end up consuming materially more video content or about the same?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mark, this is David. In general, we don't parse out the behavior. But you can imagine that people that are coming in streaming only or mostly interested in streaming will consume more than the folks on a hybrid plan. But I will say that across-the-board o
componenttext: Mark, this is David. In general, we don't parse out the behavior. But you can imagine that people that are coming in streaming only or mostly interested in streaming will consume more than the folks on a hybrid plan. But I will say that across-the-board on those plans, people do tend to consume more video when they do participate in streaming. So for the folks that avail themselves of the streaming offering, their overall video consumption is up.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mark. Can you provide more color on how you were able to drive down SAC and whether you believe the current level is sustainable?
componenttext: Our next question is from Mark. Can you provide more color on how you were able to drive down SAC and whether you believe the current level is sustainable?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mark, I think I just had that question before. So let's go to the next one.
componenttext: Mark, I think I just had that question before. So let's go to the next one.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is why would operating margins decline from 15% Q1 domestic items to 14% full year guidance?
componenttext: Our next question is why would operating margins decline from 15% Q1 domestic items to 14% full year guidance?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mark, this is David. 14% is a target. So in some quarters, it might be 13%, some might be 15%. I think we addressed the earnings rather why we're going to be a little bit heavy in Q1. We've identified a trend in our growth in shipments a little bit to put
componenttext: Mark, this is David. 14% is a target. So in some quarters, it might be 13%, some might be 15%. I think we addressed the earnings rather why we're going to be a little bit heavy in Q1. We've identified a trend in our growth in shipments a little bit to put that to work to streaming until we put a lot of work in marketing and we'll be a little bit heavy on income in Q1.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. Are the cable service providers guide or more competitors or are other any scenarios under which you might partner with them?
componenttext: The next question is from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. Are the cable service providers guide or more competitors or are other any scenarios under which you might partner with them?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The thing with the cable company, we got a natural partnership with the broadband services group, which is highly profitable and wants to increase their reach and speed at which their consumers buy packages. So the broadband side, just a complete natural
componenttext: The thing with the cable company, we got a natural partnership with the broadband services group, which is highly profitable and wants to increase their reach and speed at which their consumers buy packages. So the broadband side, just a complete natural partnership. With the video side, where a channel or sort of tolerated, we are not a big threat but it's hard to see why makes sense for them to help us grow.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is from David Miller at Caris & Company. Reed, against the backdrop of distribution services sitting up for the content in the streaming window, what is your feeling about either acquiring an equity interest in the studio or at the very leas
componenttext: Next question is from David Miller at Caris & Company. Reed, against the backdrop of distribution services sitting up for the content in the streaming window, what is your feeling about either acquiring an equity interest in the studio or at the very least starting with yourself with creative financing, you can produce script-driven content on your own at very little cost relative to the size of your P&L?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: David, generally, I'm a believer in circle of confidence and it's really the companies as they grow to step out of that. And in particular, when we start taking creative risks, that is reading script and guessing if it was going to be a big hit and who mi
componenttext: David, generally, I'm a believer in circle of confidence and it's really the companies as they grow to step out of that. And in particular, when we start taking creative risks, that is reading script and guessing if it was going to be a big hit and who might good to cast. And it's not something that as fundamentally tech company or a company run by at tech CEO like myself is likely to build distinctive organizational confidence in. And so we think that we're better off on letting other people take creative risks, get the rewards for when they do that well. And then what we do is focus on matching the different products that are made with the right consumers in sort of a very technological aspect of and streaming it. So I would say that the scenario that you outlined would be quite a change in direction and quite unlikely.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next couple of cushions are from Ryan Hunter at Wedge Partners. First, the latest report from the HI Screen Digest at some video content, DVDs, CD and vod, down about 4% to $18 billion in 2010 from 19.2 in 2009. Has this been the trend for the past fe
componenttext: The next couple of cushions are from Ryan Hunter at Wedge Partners. First, the latest report from the HI Screen Digest at some video content, DVDs, CD and vod, down about 4% to $18 billion in 2010 from 19.2 in 2009. Has this been the trend for the past few years? This has been the trend for the past few years. At what point does the market opportunity contracts and starts to impact Netflix?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'd say in general, Ryan, that vod space, we've gotten questions time and time again, there's a lot of competitors in the vod space. We've seen it in the fourth quarter, it's actually being a benefit through our 28 debuts. We've been a year with the 28 da
componenttext: I'd say in general, Ryan, that vod space, we've gotten questions time and time again, there's a lot of competitors in the vod space. We've seen it in the fourth quarter, it's actually being a benefit through our 28 debuts. We've been a year with the 28 day deals. We've seen record, low churn, record low SAC and record low growth for us. I think it's working for us. I'm sure you bought the Redbox announcement in the fourth quarter, they are a little bit nearly centric. So I hit them disproportionately. But I think what you're seeing is that an increase in the vod as a result of the dynamics in the marketplace today.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Second question from Ryan. How is the gift versus the accounted for in the subscriber count? What was the impact from the gift subscription promotion during the holidays, and what is the expected churn rate for these subscribers?
componenttext: Second question from Ryan. How is the gift versus the accounted for in the subscriber count? What was the impact from the gift subscription promotion during the holidays, and what is the expected churn rate for these subscribers?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is David. These subscribers are accounted in the subscriber count at the point where they actually entered the service and once they actually redeemed their certificate. The impacts from these subs relative to last year was relatively flat with 2009.
componenttext: This is David. These subscribers are accounted in the subscriber count at the point where they actually entered the service and once they actually redeemed their certificate. The impacts from these subs relative to last year was relatively flat with 2009. So there's not a whole lot of impact. The majority of the growth that we saw in this fourth quarter was not related to gift subs. And then expected churn rate for these subs, we don't generally comment on different segments of the business but as you can imagine, they were seeing a slightly lower rates than somebody who comes in and pays directly.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Matt BofA Merrill Lynch. Has Amazon's acquisition of, affected your plans to enter Europe? And what competitive advantages do you have over Amazon in the U.K. and Europe?
componenttext: The next question is from Matt BofA Merrill Lynch. Has Amazon's acquisition of, affected your plans to enter Europe? And what competitive advantages do you have over Amazon in the U.K. and Europe?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm not quite sure what make it obviously, Amazon within DVD rentals before sold that interest to and then bought back the whole company. And I think we're just going to have to take a couple quarters and see what they plan to do with it. And in the meant
componenttext: I'm not quite sure what make it obviously, Amazon within DVD rentals before sold that interest to and then bought back the whole company. And I think we're just going to have to take a couple quarters and see what they plan to do with it. And in the meantime, it doesn't directly affect our plan. There's vigorous competition in all these markets. So we're full speed ahead on our plans.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Imran Khan at JPMorgan. Could you please give us some color on what percentage of streaming content consumption is television shows versus movies?
componenttext: Next question is from Imran Khan at JPMorgan. Could you please give us some color on what percentage of streaming content consumption is television shows versus movies?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. What we said before is, it's roughly half-and-half now and there's some variation fourth-quarter but that's a rough range.
componenttext: Sure. What we said before is, it's roughly half-and-half now and there's some variation fourth-quarter but that's a rough range.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next one is from Ingrid Chung at Goldman Sachs. You've spoken about geographic expansion beyond Canada in the second half of this year. If you can tell us which countries specifically are most interesting to you? Could you tell us what some of the charact
componenttext: Next one is from Ingrid Chung at Goldman Sachs. You've spoken about geographic expansion beyond Canada in the second half of this year. If you can tell us which countries specifically are most interesting to you? Could you tell us what some of the characteristics are of an attractive market other than high broadband penetration? Would you want to be in a market with high or low pay TV penetration or does that matter?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ingrid, it's more complicated question as you probably understand than just pay-TV or not. It's really the best use of the dollars for building a business in the country that is it likely to be a sustainable source of profit. And so that's a mix of how co
componenttext: Ingrid, it's more complicated question as you probably understand than just pay-TV or not. It's really the best use of the dollars for building a business in the country that is it likely to be a sustainable source of profit. And so that's a mix of how competitive it is, how good the broadband is, what content rights we can get, what's the economic growth rate, what's piracy. Boy, there is a whole ton of factors that is underlying that. But I would say is wherever we go next is just one building block and our hope is to be able to go country-by-country and to expand quite rapidly in 2012 and 2013 assuming we continue to see kind of success that we've seen in Canada.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next couple of questions are from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS. Can you give us a sense of how the newer free subs are converting to paying subs from Canada or from most free subs that are part of the extended full week offer? How is it different from the
componenttext: The next couple of questions are from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS. Can you give us a sense of how the newer free subs are converting to paying subs from Canada or from most free subs that are part of the extended full week offer? How is it different from the historic convention rate?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say as we grow, we would expect and with streaming only, it's a little more casual relationship than it is easier to get in and easier to get out. And that, that is going to tend to inflate growth add and inflate churn. Again, the net adds come ou
componenttext: I would say as we grow, we would expect and with streaming only, it's a little more casual relationship than it is easier to get in and easier to get out. And that, that is going to tend to inflate growth add and inflate churn. Again, the net adds come out off with the same place but you get -- that's how it affects those two metrics.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then the second question, any initial impact you're seeing to churn based on from the recent price changes?
componenttext: And then the second question, any initial impact you're seeing to churn based on from the recent price changes?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, nothing material.
componenttext: No, nothing material.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Jason Chiu with AVR Investment Strategy. Generally speaking, what percent of new sub adds in the quarter were driven by Internet connected videogame consoles versus mobile devices such as smart phones and tablets? How important are t
componenttext: Next question is from Jason Chiu with AVR Investment Strategy. Generally speaking, what percent of new sub adds in the quarter were driven by Internet connected videogame consoles versus mobile devices such as smart phones and tablets? How important are these devices for your international expansion?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jason, we don't break out how or which are those are driving our marketing. And I would say, they're all important in international expansion, proportional really to the size of their installed base in a given country.
componenttext: Jason, we don't break out how or which are those are driving our marketing. And I would say, they're all important in international expansion, proportional really to the size of their installed base in a given country.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Couple questions from Daniel Ernst at Hudson Square Research. In your letter to investors, you've discussed the desire to work with studios to have content cash outlays, better matching expensing, which I presume would mean lower upfront cost and better s
componenttext: Couple questions from Daniel Ernst at Hudson Square Research. In your letter to investors, you've discussed the desire to work with studios to have content cash outlays, better matching expensing, which I presume would mean lower upfront cost and better scaling with usage and subscribers. Are there other examples in content licensing that you can model that plan after? On the flipside, TV syndication deals do require substantial upfront. Therefore, what is the prospect for getting content on a precede upfront payment?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, almost all of our deals, Daniel, right now match cash with expense and you see that in our cash flow for Q4. So it's really just a question of each shift, the two sides relative to the cost of capital, and most studios and content would do with that l
componenttext: No, almost all of our deals, Daniel, right now match cash with expense and you see that in our cash flow for Q4. So it's really just a question of each shift, the two sides relative to the cost of capital, and most studios and content would do with that lower cost of capital than we do. So it's not that hard an issue.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: If I can add something, this is David. We have been able to get a number of deals where the payments terms are matching the expense. So it's not like there is not a person out there. As you pointed out in the indication market, we're evolving with that ma
componenttext: If I can add something, this is David. We have been able to get a number of deals where the payments terms are matching the expense. So it's not like there is not a person out there. As you pointed out in the indication market, we're evolving with that marketplace.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Jason Helfstein from Oppenheimer and Co. In your comments, you talk about the current $7.99 per month plan. It's for one stream at a time even though today's company does not limit concurrent stream. Is there any data you can share a
componenttext: Next question is from Jason Helfstein from Oppenheimer and Co. In your comments, you talk about the current $7.99 per month plan. It's for one stream at a time even though today's company does not limit concurrent stream. Is there any data you can share about what percentage currency of households trends and you see today? Secondly, if you're thinking about plan economics, what type of price points seem like a fair value to you?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: We don't have a very sudden number of concurrent streams, Jason. And think of it as if there's one concurrent instance in the year, that subscriber or is that household is likely to spend to get a separate account. There has to be a pretty frequent confli
componenttext: We don't have a very sudden number of concurrent streams, Jason. And think of it as if there's one concurrent instance in the year, that subscriber or is that household is likely to spend to get a separate account. There has to be a pretty frequent conflict. So it's not at how many Concord incidences it, might be related to a simple how many people have more than multi-concurrent stream per week or something, that will affect how well we can drive the evolution to individual accounts. And when you talk about family economics, we'll pass the range of scenarios and try to figure out the consumers view of what's a fair and appropriate option. But that will be second half of this year at earliest and may flip into 2012 before we get into that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question from Steve Rivers of Stifel, Nicolaus. Can you provide details on how many subscribers trends view Watch Instantly during the quarter? Can you provide any details regarding what is utilization in the Bay Area as well as the rest of the count
componenttext: Next question from Steve Rivers of Stifel, Nicolaus. Can you provide details on how many subscribers trends view Watch Instantly during the quarter? Can you provide any details regarding what is utilization in the Bay Area as well as the rest of the country?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: We can tell you, Steve, it's continue to increase like it had in the prior quarters. There's been no real change in the trend. And that it's great in the Bay Area, great within the rest of the country and generally streaming continue its tremendous growth
componenttext: We can tell you, Steve, it's continue to increase like it had in the prior quarters. There's been no real change in the trend. And that it's great in the Bay Area, great within the rest of the country and generally streaming continue its tremendous growth for us.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Usually you provide the stock comp expense associated with several categories of the P&L. You did not provide this information this quarter. Are you changing your reporting policies? And if not, can you provide that data?
componenttext: Usually you provide the stock comp expense associated with several categories of the P&L. You did not provide this information this quarter. Are you changing your reporting policies? And if not, can you provide that data?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Steve, this is David. There's no cause for alarm. That information will be continued to report in the Q and the K in the footnote. It's just a matter of cleaning up the earnings release, trying to get some real estate.
componenttext: Steve, this is David. There's no cause for alarm. That information will be continued to report in the Q and the K in the footnote. It's just a matter of cleaning up the earnings release, trying to get some real estate.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Doug Anmuth at Barclays. How would you potentially implement the shift in a household service to that of an individual subscriber? Is there any data you can share with us on simultaneous streaming? And is this a good strategic thing
componenttext: Next question is from Doug Anmuth at Barclays. How would you potentially implement the shift in a household service to that of an individual subscriber? Is there any data you can share with us on simultaneous streaming? And is this a good strategic thing to do in the face of potentially more streaming competition, what do you view as the core benefits to individual subscribers?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The question really is, Doug, is video naturally because of the portable devices, the laptop, the pads, the phones, and the individual relationships like e-mails and individual relationship with mobile phone. And somewhat it is, and somewhat it isn't beca
componenttext: The question really is, Doug, is video naturally because of the portable devices, the laptop, the pads, the phones, and the individual relationships like e-mails and individual relationship with mobile phone. And somewhat it is, and somewhat it isn't because of the use of the shared screens also. And so what we have to do is try some things with subscribers to see how comfortable that notion of a personal subscription really is and what are the advantages in terms of increased personalization, better Facebook integration, some sort of a relationship compared to the complexities of it. But we would certainly like to -- we will be working towards having it evolved to be an individual relationship over time.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question from Doug. I understand the business is changing in realtime, but can you explain in more detail why you're not guiding for the full year?
componenttext: Next question from Doug. I understand the business is changing in realtime, but can you explain in more detail why you're not guiding for the full year?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: One, I think generally, we can find the guidance from last year so far off that. And that I'm not sure it's very relevant that business is moving so quickly. So we did get some guidance for the year that we expect net adds to continue to grow and margin.
componenttext: One, I think generally, we can find the guidance from last year so far off that. And that I'm not sure it's very relevant that business is moving so quickly. So we did get some guidance for the year that we expect net adds to continue to grow and margin. but how much gross I think from last year you can clearly see that we're not a distinguished authority. So that's really the reason behind it.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And finally from Doug. Canada, do you believe usage base pricing among broadband providers in Canada is having any impact on net subscriber count overall usage? Do people fully understand that they might need to pay more for broadband when using Netflix?
componenttext: And finally from Doug. Canada, do you believe usage base pricing among broadband providers in Canada is having any impact on net subscriber count overall usage? Do people fully understand that they might need to pay more for broadband when using Netflix?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Doug, we are definitely worried about. And my sense is that those Canadians wit h cap of $1 or $2 per gigabyte overcharges. Many of them probably don't understand their plan and it will take a billing cycle or two for them, and that is potentia significan
componenttext: Doug, we are definitely worried about. And my sense is that those Canadians wit h cap of $1 or $2 per gigabyte overcharges. Many of them probably don't understand their plan and it will take a billing cycle or two for them, and that is potentia significant negative for Netflix. The shame of it is it's got the marginal cost as we wrote in the letter to deliver a marginal gigabyte overwired network is extremely small, well less than a $0.01. So hopefully, we can work within a different consumer groups and providers, and get a better costing structure where if there are paper and gigabyte charges, they're more in the $0.01 range or they are bundled in with a much higher cap like it exists in the U.S. and in many other nations.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Edward Williams at BMO Capital Markets. Another Canadian question. Regarding Canada, how long will it take to get to comparable penetration rates in Canada as compared to the U.S. .
componenttext: Next question is from Edward Williams at BMO Capital Markets. Another Canadian question. Regarding Canada, how long will it take to get to comparable penetration rates in Canada as compared to the U.S. .

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is David. We don't talk specifics but it's not hard to see from our guidance for Q1 that Canada is doing much faster than it did in the U.S.. So in terms of putting an actual number out there, I don't think we'd be wanted to talk to that. But suffice
componenttext: This is David. We don't talk specifics but it's not hard to see from our guidance for Q1 that Canada is doing much faster than it did in the U.S.. So in terms of putting an actual number out there, I don't think we'd be wanted to talk to that. But suffice to say, is we're going much faster in Canada than in the U.S.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jeffrey the Hubert Value Fund. What did APA increased so much?
componenttext: The next question is from Jeffrey the Hubert Value Fund. What did APA increased so much?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's Zachary from Zachary? This is David. APA increase, if you look at the balance sheet and the cash flow statement, you'll notice that we had a significant increase in the investment on our streaming content library until a couple of these are large pay
componenttext: It's Zachary from Zachary? This is David. APA increase, if you look at the balance sheet and the cash flow statement, you'll notice that we had a significant increase in the investment on our streaming content library until a couple of these are large payments that in the short timing at the end of the quarter and that should reversed themselves in Q1.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Richard Greenfield at DTIJ. As you move away from your DVD Buynow business, what do you foresee as your greatest competitive advantage in streaming as we presume that at some point competition will actually materialize and does not a
componenttext: Next question is from Richard Greenfield at DTIJ. As you move away from your DVD Buynow business, what do you foresee as your greatest competitive advantage in streaming as we presume that at some point competition will actually materialize and does not appear that the vast majority of your contents is exclusive?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Richard, it's Reed. I think our primary competitive advantage is subscriber base, and that allows us to get more content on a fixed cost basis to do more R&D, to market more. So there's a lot of virtual cycles around the subscriber base size that we refer
componenttext: Richard, it's Reed. I think our primary competitive advantage is subscriber base, and that allows us to get more content on a fixed cost basis to do more R&D, to market more. So there's a lot of virtual cycles around the subscriber base size that we referred to in the letter. And that's how I would look at the primary competitive advantages.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Doug Mitchelson at Deutsche Bank Securities. Do you believe that we'll get harder to acquire incremental films and TV shows from major Hollywood studios? And where are you in quantity today and where would you hope to be in a few
componenttext: The next question is from Doug Mitchelson at Deutsche Bank Securities. Do you believe that we'll get harder to acquire incremental films and TV shows from major Hollywood studios? And where are you in quantity today and where would you hope to be in a few years?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Doug, no it's not gotten harder. It's gotten as we pay more. Three or four years ago when we couldn't pay much, very hard. And now, because we got significant dollars to spend, we got people coming to us and that makes perfect sense. So we're feeling grea
componenttext: Doug, no it's not gotten harder. It's gotten as we pay more. Three or four years ago when we couldn't pay much, very hard. And now, because we got significant dollars to spend, we got people coming to us and that makes perfect sense. So we're feeling great about both our ability to make content owners a lot of money and get the field done and continue to fill out and improve our selection.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I have a question from Jason Epstein of Oppenheimer. Do you think netbooks success is what is hurting Redbox. Are you willing to comment on what hurt consumer demand for products in Q4? And does this make Redbox partnership more or less likely?
componenttext: I have a question from Jason Epstein of Oppenheimer. Do you think netbooks success is what is hurting Redbox. Are you willing to comment on what hurt consumer demand for products in Q4? And does this make Redbox partnership more or less likely?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm pretty confident that our success is not what's hurting Redbox because DVDs were barely up for us. And I think the Redbox was up 30% or something. So I think those are really unrelated issues. And of course, our streaming content is not the newest DVD
componenttext: I'm pretty confident that our success is not what's hurting Redbox because DVDs were barely up for us. And I think the Redbox was up 30% or something. So I think those are really unrelated issues. And of course, our streaming content is not the newest DVD releases and that's what Redbox focuses on is the newest DVD releases. But I don't really have more to say, about Redbox. It is a partnership more or less likely. I don't think it was ever that likely. We are super focused on streaming and unlimited streaming. They're focused on new release DVD and they are doing a great job at what they do.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question from Stephen Spangle at Dougherty. What's the timing on introducing the Facebook innovation?
componenttext: Next question from Stephen Spangle at Dougherty. What's the timing on introducing the Facebook innovation?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll be rolling that out in phases over this year, sort of quarter-by-quarter and month-by-month and will get better and better and better.
componenttext: We'll be rolling that out in phases over this year, sort of quarter-by-quarter and month-by-month and will get better and better and better.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And second question from Steven Finkel, at 20 million subscribers and growing, you have the scale to compete head-to-head with some traditional pay-TV services for first-run movies. As the of studio in HBO and others expire, is it likely the Netflix compe
componenttext: And second question from Steven Finkel, at 20 million subscribers and growing, you have the scale to compete head-to-head with some traditional pay-TV services for first-run movies. As the of studio in HBO and others expire, is it likely the Netflix competes for titles on an exclusive basis?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: It certainly is possible that we would compete on an exclusive basis. We'll do that if we have to. But we think we can make more economic sense for us and pay television to share Windows conceptually each paying 2/3 and the studio getting one in the what
componenttext: It certainly is possible that we would compete on an exclusive basis. We'll do that if we have to. But we think we can make more economic sense for us and pay television to share Windows conceptually each paying 2/3 and the studio getting one in the what they're getting the past. So we tend to try to look for deals like that to make the content owners more money. And allow the other aggregators to pay a little less. But we are basically very flexible and just want to find good ways to expand the content.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Michael from Piper Jaffray. We're would most of the affects from the international fall? Will it be in marketing for the Netflix brands or is that up full moon?
componenttext: Michael from Piper Jaffray. We're would most of the affects from the international fall? Will it be in marketing for the Netflix brands or is that up full moon?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mike, this is David. I'd say that you can roughly what we said in the past is that each international investment put virtually between marketing and streaming content and that's what hold in the future.
componenttext: Mike, this is David. I'd say that you can roughly what we said in the past is that each international investment put virtually between marketing and streaming content and that's what hold in the future.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Mark Barton Crockett at Lazard regarding international expansion. When you look at countries to expand into, do you see any desirable countries with meaningful incumbent providers of online subscription streaming services that you ha
componenttext: Next question is from Mark Barton Crockett at Lazard regarding international expansion. When you look at countries to expand into, do you see any desirable countries with meaningful incumbent providers of online subscription streaming services that you have to compete with? How does competition and the risk of losing battle factor into your choice of countries to enter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Martin, you would expect that's one of the two factors. Typically in the markets that are the biggest drivers, already there's vigorous competition so it's a trade-off there. So we'll try a variety of things over the years both in markets that already hav
componenttext: Martin, you would expect that's one of the two factors. Typically in the markets that are the biggest drivers, already there's vigorous competition so it's a trade-off there. So we'll try a variety of things over the years both in markets that already have competitors, also in markets that don't at the type that you're describing. So I'd say, we tend to try to put our money in play where we think it has the best chance of a big sustainable return. And as I mentioned earlier to Ingrid, there's a lot of fact that go into that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next which and is from Jim Friedland at Cowen. Are you using AWS in Canada? Will you be able to use AWS in the future and international launches?
componenttext: The next which and is from Jim Friedland at Cowen. Are you using AWS in Canada? Will you be able to use AWS in the future and international launches?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. AWS is a very global already and we'll continue to use AWS.
componenttext: Sure. AWS is a very global already and we'll continue to use AWS.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Ken Johnson, an individual investor. What is your purpose perspective on national growth in non-English speaking markets? Would Netflix consider licensing a significant amount of non-english content of streaming to countries like Ind
componenttext: Next question is from Ken Johnson, an individual investor. What is your purpose perspective on national growth in non-English speaking markets? Would Netflix consider licensing a significant amount of non-english content of streaming to countries like India and/or China, perhaps the Spanish speaking world?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. We don't limit ourselves in terms of our circle of confidence to english-language content. In fact, we're a very big licensee of foreign content already for the U.S. market. And we feel very comfortable licensing content for a variety of interest. A
componenttext: Sure. We don't limit ourselves in terms of our circle of confidence to english-language content. In fact, we're a very big licensee of foreign content already for the U.S. market. And we feel very comfortable licensing content for a variety of interest. And really, it's our global process knowledge and our technology that's globally relevant. And by technology, I mean both on the streaming side and on the merchandising are matching which people tend to like which titles.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. We estimate netbooks' domestic sale set to pass through HBO in 2012, trends recently suggested that netbook's sort of aggressively bid for Warner Bros content. And Warner's current arrangement with HBO
componenttext: Next question is from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. We estimate netbooks' domestic sale set to pass through HBO in 2012, trends recently suggested that netbook's sort of aggressively bid for Warner Bros content. And Warner's current arrangement with HBO expired in 2014. Given that HBO and Warner Bros. are owned by the same parent, a parent that has made several negative public comments about your business. Can you explain the dynamics here and how it is possible that by bidding for the content, you could either get it or if HBO to pay more for it?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not sure I agree on the negative comments aspect. The press makes a living out of blowing some things up and we're nearly $100 million customer for Warner Bros. and both of us would like to expand that, if it makes sense to. In terms of specific
componenttext: Well, I'm not sure I agree on the negative comments aspect. The press makes a living out of blowing some things up and we're nearly $100 million customer for Warner Bros. and both of us would like to expand that, if it makes sense to. In terms of specifically bidding on the Warner Bros. content, that may be advantageous for us and maybe that we end up again doing a share with Warner Bros. makes more money than they would have otherwise in both HBO and offset content, it could be a range of our options in that. So and clearly, they will make a strategic decision based upon the different interest of the different divisions, but they are quite comfortable having us bid on it, they're not trying to exclude us in any way.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Tony Wible at Janney Montgomery Scott. Do you believe that the move to variable-based distribution cost i.e. the SEC usage base going that has prompted some ISPs to consider telling what service companies. And the first price content
componenttext: Next question is from Tony Wible at Janney Montgomery Scott. Do you believe that the move to variable-based distribution cost i.e. the SEC usage base going that has prompted some ISPs to consider telling what service companies. And the first price content on the variable basis will fundamentally change the way netbooks prices or tiers its service?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Tony, it's a risk, particularly if paper gigabyte be it a dollar per gigabyte model for ISPs to cold. And so we will be involved in that debate. And again, since the cost of delivering, if you could buy or less than a $0.01 and falling, we don't mak
componenttext: Well, Tony, it's a risk, particularly if paper gigabyte be it a dollar per gigabyte model for ISPs to cold. And so we will be involved in that debate. And again, since the cost of delivering, if you could buy or less than a $0.01 and falling, we don't make it terribly likely but we don't want to be asleep at the switch and just let that happen.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Second question from Tony. Do you expect Google, Amazon and/or Apple to be a more formidable competitor in 2011?
componenttext: Second question from Tony. Do you expect Google, Amazon and/or Apple to be a more formidable competitor in 2011?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Definitely, there's a lot of firms including the ones you mentioned that could be more direct competitor with us. The internet is creating a ton of opportunity for a lot of firms and there's all top models between the pay-per-view models for new releases,
componenttext: Definitely, there's a lot of firms including the ones you mentioned that could be more direct competitor with us. The internet is creating a ton of opportunity for a lot of firms and there's all top models between the pay-per-view models for new releases, the ad-supported model. So there's a lot of different companies with different strengths. But as you know, we've been through a lot of competition in the past. We view that as a natural part of the process and we're just focused on building up as best as we can.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is from John Blackledge of Crdit Suisse. What was the decline in disk shipments per subscriber per month in Q4 on a year-over-year basis. I think in Q3, these shipments were down 24% year-over-year. Just wondering if the declines were
componenttext: The next question is from John Blackledge of Crdit Suisse. What was the decline in disk shipments per subscriber per month in Q4 on a year-over-year basis. I think in Q3, these shipments were down 24% year-over-year. Just wondering if the declines were on the same level or accelerating?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: John, we don't publish shipment information like that. So I'm not sure where you got that in Q3 quote. What we said in the letter and I will remind you is, disk shipments did actually continue to grow, they just grew a lower rate than we expected. And goi
componenttext: John, we don't publish shipment information like that. So I'm not sure where you got that in Q3 quote. What we said in the letter and I will remind you is, disk shipments did actually continue to grow, they just grew a lower rate than we expected. And going into the fourth quarter, we already knew that we're going to offer a price change and a new plant offering on the streaming-only plan starting in late November. There was some uncertainty around the take rate on that plan and how would that affect our disk shipments. And so we are a little bit conservative in terms of planning out the number of shipment and I think you see that reflected in lower shipments.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Matt of BofA Merrill. The comments in the text about charging for multiple strings per account is somewhat confusing to me. Are you planning to only limit the 799 plan to a single stream or are you expecting to limit all plans to
componenttext: The next question is from Matt of BofA Merrill. The comments in the text about charging for multiple strings per account is somewhat confusing to me. Are you planning to only limit the 799 plan to a single stream or are you expecting to limit all plans to a single stream at a time?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Both the $9.99 1-out the DVD and the $7.99, while one screen at the time. And the vast majority of subscribers are on one of those two plans. So you can think of it as a vast majority of subscribers are on a one-stream at a time plan. So as we develop mod
componenttext: Both the $9.99 1-out the DVD and the $7.99, while one screen at the time. And the vast majority of subscribers are on one of those two plans. So you can think of it as a vast majority of subscribers are on a one-stream at a time plan. So as we develop models around upgrades and how do you get either multiple streams on an account or multiple accounts or subaccounts, those are the kinds of things that we will be testing and evolving over the coming quarters.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Justin Patterson at Morgan Keegan. With regards to your experience in Canada, how was it tracking versus your initial expectations? What's your biggest challenge in the region? What lessons have you learned but you can take to ad
componenttext: The next question is from Justin Patterson at Morgan Keegan. With regards to your experience in Canada, how was it tracking versus your initial expectations? What's your biggest challenge in the region? What lessons have you learned but you can take to additional international markets?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the main lesson we've learned is confidence in the model. We were really unclear as to how well and aggressively priced on-demand Internet service with work, without all the DVD and brand history, can we get a cost-efficient marketing and get subs
componenttext: I think the main lesson we've learned is confidence in the model. We were really unclear as to how well and aggressively priced on-demand Internet service with work, without all the DVD and brand history, can we get a cost-efficient marketing and get subscribers to sign up? And in fact, we've proven ourselves that at least within the conditions in Canada that, that is indeed very possible and we did very happy with the growth. And so then we'll take on a little bit bigger challenge and we've learned mostly to have confidence in the model of on-demand streaming.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Michael Pachter at Wedbush Securities. How long do you expect fixed-price contracts to be offered? Do you foresee a migration to a cost per subscriber model much as it's used by cable companies in dealing with content providers?
componenttext: Next question is from Michael Pachter at Wedbush Securities. How long do you expect fixed-price contracts to be offered? Do you foresee a migration to a cost per subscriber model much as it's used by cable companies in dealing with content providers?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Michael, that's a possibility but it's not very likely. I think what is happening is the contracts, some of the contracts are short. So you can think of fixed cost for a year or two, it's really just a high granularity variable contract based upon the siz
componenttext: Michael, that's a possibility but it's not very likely. I think what is happening is the contracts, some of the contracts are short. So you can think of fixed cost for a year or two, it's really just a high granularity variable contract based upon the size. And so, I would guess that would go that way. We definitely agree with some model that as we grow bigger, any individual piece of content is more valuable to us and we'll end up paying more for it. But I think the form will be upon renewals of short-term deals.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question from use of Youssef Squali in Jefferies. Can you speak about net neutrality in Europe?
componenttext: Next question from use of Youssef Squali in Jefferies. Can you speak about net neutrality in Europe?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Youssef, net neutrality is a pretty strong concept in Europe. So no, no significant risks there. The aspect of the open regional, no charges interchange, however, is less strongly, and that's probably the big issue, which is can ISPs charge content provid
componenttext: Youssef, net neutrality is a pretty strong concept in Europe. So no, no significant risks there. The aspect of the open regional, no charges interchange, however, is less strongly, and that's probably the big issue, which is can ISPs charge content providers like YouTube and Netflix and Amazon, a significant fee to serve their customers? And so that's probably where that interest in the friction will be?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question from Peter Cheviot at EMS Capital. What do you think is the operating margin potential of the company is at maturity? How do you think about the range of outcomes?
componenttext: Next question from Peter Cheviot at EMS Capital. What do you think is the operating margin potential of the company is at maturity? How do you think about the range of outcomes?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Peter, in prior calls, what I've said is the long term even the majority operating margins in the industry are really determined by the number of competitors. So if there's three or four roughly equal-sized competitors in maturity, you'd expect pretty low
componenttext: Peter, in prior calls, what I've said is the long term even the majority operating margins in the industry are really determined by the number of competitors. So if there's three or four roughly equal-sized competitors in maturity, you'd expect pretty low operating margins. If there's one firm that's the leading from the market, you'd expect higher operating margins. So it really depends upon the competitive environment as supposed to something inherent in the cost structure.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Andy Hargreaves at Pacific Crest Securities. As your subscriber base grows and substream more content, are you concerned about running into the limits of total bandwidth availability in a given geography?
componenttext: The next question is from Andy Hargreaves at Pacific Crest Securities. As your subscriber base grows and substream more content, are you concerned about running into the limits of total bandwidth availability in a given geography?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Oh, gosh. Not at all. We recently got a calculation about fiber optics and what we discovered is that a single fiber optic, about the size of a human hair, because of the advances in dents weight division multiplexing can now carry all 100% of the Netflix
componenttext: Oh, gosh. Not at all. We recently got a calculation about fiber optics and what we discovered is that a single fiber optic, about the size of a human hair, because of the advances in dents weight division multiplexing can now carry all 100% of the Netflix traffic. So if we had a single data center where all the bits came out of, it could comfortably go out in a single fiber. And furthermore, the improvements in the next three years expected in fiber optics are increasing that number. So I would say the rate of innovation in data transmission, especially in fiber is greatly outstripping any growth that we could possibly get to.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is a follow-up question from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS, following up on the climbing shipment question. In the letter you say, that you expect these shipments to decline year-over-year in the coming quarters. Is this the first time you pointed
componenttext: Next question is a follow-up question from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS, following up on the climbing shipment question. In the letter you say, that you expect these shipments to decline year-over-year in the coming quarters. Is this the first time you pointed to this? Did you move this inflection point forward?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Brian, this is Dave. This is the first time that we talked about this. And it's largely a function of a plan mix that's streaming off for streaming only plan offering and just the embrace of the streaming-only offering service in general.
componenttext: Brian, this is Dave. This is the first time that we talked about this. And it's largely a function of a plan mix that's streaming off for streaming only plan offering and just the embrace of the streaming-only offering service in general.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's the last question I have. We'd like to thank everyone for your time and we look forward to talking to you again next quarter.
componenttext: That's the last question I have. We'd like to thank everyone for your time and we look forward to talking to you again next quarter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: That concludes the call. Have a great day.
componenttext: That concludes the call. Have a great day.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and Welcome to the Netflix Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I will turn the call over to Deborah Crawford, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and Welcome to the Netflix Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I will turn the call over to Deborah Crawford, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. We announced our financial results for the fourth quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific time today. The shareholder letter and the Q4 financial results an
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Q&A Session. We announced our financial results for the fourth quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific time today. The shareholder letter and the Q4 financial results and the webcast of this Q&A session are all available at the company's Investor Relations website at ir.netflix.com. 
As is our standard practice, this call will consist solely of Q&A and we are going to conduct the Q&A via e-mail. Please e-mail your questions to IR@netflix.com. 
We may make forward-looking statements during this call regarding the company's future performance. Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to risks and uncertainties related to the business. A detailed discussion of such risks and uncertainties is contained in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the Commission on February 22, 2010. A rebroadcast of this Q&A session will be available at the Netflix website after 6:00 p.m. Pacific time today. Before we begin the Q&A, I'd like to turn the call over to Reed.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Deborah. I'd just like to acknowledge that Darren McCarthy has been our CFO and my partner for the last 11 years, and there's no way we would've gotten to 20 million subscribers as fast as we did without his incredible work. And I'm thrilled to be
componenttext: Thanks, Deborah. I'd just like to acknowledge that Darren McCarthy has been our CFO and my partner for the last 11 years, and there's no way we would've gotten to 20 million subscribers as fast as we did without his incredible work. And I'm thrilled to be able to introduce to you, David Wells, who's our new CFO.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Reed. This is David. I'm glad to be joining on the earnings call this afternoon. I've got quite a legacy to follow. I've been part of the Netflix team for seven years and in the background of this call for many of those years. So I look for
componenttext: Great. Thanks, Reed. This is David. I'm glad to be joining on the earnings call this afternoon. I've got quite a legacy to follow. I've been part of the Netflix team for seven years and in the background of this call for many of those years. So I look forward to speaking to many of you in the coming weeks. But I know that you're here for Q&A, so let's get to questions.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The first question is from Youssef Squali of Jefferies & Company. How should we think about overall content spend in 2011 versus 2010 mix of international and domestic digital rights?
componenttext: The first question is from Youssef Squali of Jefferies & Company. How should we think about overall content spend in 2011 versus 2010 mix of international and domestic digital rights?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Youssef, I can actually take that. This is David. I think you should mostly think of it as domestic. If you think about the guidance that we gave for Q1 and you scale that for Q2, and you think about the $50 million operating loss we talked about in Q3 an
componenttext: Youssef, I can actually take that. This is David. I think you should mostly think of it as domestic. If you think about the guidance that we gave for Q1 and you scale that for Q2, and you think about the $50 million operating loss we talked about in Q3 and 4, it's not hard to get to a position where most of that spend is domestic.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Arthuros Mangriotis at Fox Point Capital Management. Please elaborate on your decision to reduce focus on churn. Even though net additions are ultimately the important statistics, I would've thought that managing churn would be a
componenttext: The next question is from Arthuros Mangriotis at Fox Point Capital Management. Please elaborate on your decision to reduce focus on churn. Even though net additions are ultimately the important statistics, I would've thought that managing churn would be a great way to make sure you are satisfying your customers.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Arthuros, it's Reed here. I guess, I'd say, you don't really manage churn. You manage satisfaction. And then from higher satisfaction comes more word-of-mouth, driving SAC down and new starts up and churn down. And what I've come to realize over the years
componenttext: Arthuros, it's Reed here. I guess, I'd say, you don't really manage churn. You manage satisfaction. And then from higher satisfaction comes more word-of-mouth, driving SAC down and new starts up and churn down. And what I've come to realize over the years is that net adds is really the best indicator of that. And this evolution in our part reflects an internal evolution over the past couple of years, where I find myself not particularly paying attention to churn in fact and much more than net adds, which again is the best indicator of the satisfaction. And so that's the underlying reason for the evolution.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Heath Terry at Canaccord Genuity. How do marketing deals like the Netflix button on remote controls compare to your existing subscriber acquisition cost level?
componenttext: The next question is from Heath Terry at Canaccord Genuity. How do marketing deals like the Netflix button on remote controls compare to your existing subscriber acquisition cost level?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Heath, we don't know for sure yet, because I guess we would say, we don't know the effectiveness of the buttons. It feels like a great option. And once they're in the market, which should be in the middle of this year and then more later in the year, we'l
componenttext: Heath, we don't know for sure yet, because I guess we would say, we don't know the effectiveness of the buttons. It feels like a great option. And once they're in the market, which should be in the middle of this year and then more later in the year, we'll be able to study really how much consumers use them. So we're optimistic on it. We think it's a great direction, but we don't have any hard evidence yet and we won't probably for a year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Second question from Heath. Is the improving market for online advertising impacting your online SAC level?
componenttext: Second question from Heath. Is the improving market for online advertising impacting your online SAC level?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Not substantially, Heath. It's been pretty steady for us. The big thing that improved SAC is that we didn't spend that much on marketing in the quarter, because it was earning so much on streaming. And when you spend less on marketing, you can think of it
componenttext: Not substantially, Heath. It's been pretty steady for us. The big thing that improved SAC is that we didn't spend that much on marketing in the quarter, because it was earning so much on streaming. And when you spend less on marketing, you can think of it skimming the market or you can think of it as we get the flow over from the prior quarters kind of brand build up, it carries us. And when we go into Q1, we'll spend a little more in marketing. In fact it'll be a little higher. So it's generally in the right direction but not as low as it was in Q4.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next set of questions are from Mark Mahaney at Citi Investment Research. First question, what can you disclose about the overall usage patterns of streaming only or streaming mostly subscribers versus your DVD-rental subscribers? Do they end up consum
componenttext: The next set of questions are from Mark Mahaney at Citi Investment Research. First question, what can you disclose about the overall usage patterns of streaming only or streaming mostly subscribers versus your DVD-rental subscribers? Do they end up consuming materially more video content or about the same?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mark, this is David. In general, we don't parse out the behavior. But you can imagine that people that are coming in streaming only or mostly interested in streaming will consume more than the folks on a hybrid plan. But I will say that across the board o
componenttext: Mark, this is David. In general, we don't parse out the behavior. But you can imagine that people that are coming in streaming only or mostly interested in streaming will consume more than the folks on a hybrid plan. But I will say that across the board on those plans, people do tend to consume more video when they do participate in streaming. So for the folks that avail themselves of the streaming offering, their overall video consumption goes up.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And the next question from Mark, can you provide more color on how you were able to drive down SAC and whether you believe the current level is sustainable?
componenttext: And the next question from Mark, can you provide more color on how you were able to drive down SAC and whether you believe the current level is sustainable?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mark, I think I just had that question before. So let's go to the next one.
componenttext: Mark, I think I just had that question before. So let's go to the next one.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is why would operating margins decline from 15% Q1 domestic items to 14% full year guidance?
componenttext: Our next question is why would operating margins decline from 15% Q1 domestic items to 14% full year guidance?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mark, this is David. 14% is a target. So some quarters, it might be 13%, some might be 15%. I think we addressed the earnings letter why we're going to be a little bit heavy in Q1. We've identified a trend in our growth in shipments a little bit two-way t
componenttext: Mark, this is David. 14% is a target. So some quarters, it might be 13%, some might be 15%. I think we addressed the earnings letter why we're going to be a little bit heavy in Q1. We've identified a trend in our growth in shipments a little bit two-way to put that to work to streaming. And so we put a lot of it to work in marketing and we'll be a little bit heavy on income in Q1.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. Are the cable service providers diving into role of competitors [ph] or are other any scenarios under which you might partner with them?
componenttext: The next question is from Ben Rose at Battle Road Research. Are the cable service providers diving into role of competitors [ph] or are other any scenarios under which you might partner with them?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The thing with the cable company, we've got a natural partnership with the broadband services group, which is highly profitable and wants to increase their reach and the speed at which their consumers buy packages. So with the broadband side, there's a co
componenttext: The thing with the cable company, we've got a natural partnership with the broadband services group, which is highly profitable and wants to increase their reach and the speed at which their consumers buy packages. So with the broadband side, there's a complete natural partnership. With the video side, we're a channel, we're sort of tolerated. We're not a big threat, but it's hard to see why it makes sense for them to help us grow.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is from David Miller at Caris & Company. Reed, against the backdrop of other distribution services sitting up for the content in the streaming window, what is your feeling about either acquiring an equity interest in the studio or at the ver
componenttext: Next question is from David Miller at Caris & Company. Reed, against the backdrop of other distribution services sitting up for the content in the streaming window, what is your feeling about either acquiring an equity interest in the studio or at the very least, starting one yourself?
