componenttext: The next question is from Doug Mitchelson at Deutsche Bank Securities. Do you believe that it will get harder to acquire incremental films and TV shows from major Hollywood studios? And where are you in quantity today? And where would you hope to be in a few years?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Doug, no it's not gotten harder. It's gotten easier as we pay more. Three or four years ago when we couldn't pay much, it was very hard. And now, because we got significant dollars to spend, we got people coming to us and that makes perfect sense. So we'r
componenttext: Doug, no it's not gotten harder. It's gotten easier as we pay more. Three or four years ago when we couldn't pay much, it was very hard. And now, because we got significant dollars to spend, we got people coming to us and that makes perfect sense. So we're feeling great about both our ability to make content owners a lot of money and get deals done and continue to fill out and improve our selection.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Another question from Jason Helfstein at Oppenheimer. Do you think Netflix' success is what is hurting Redbox? Are you willing to comment on what hurt consumer demand for their products in Q4? And does this make a Redbox partnership more or less likely?
componenttext: Another question from Jason Helfstein at Oppenheimer. Do you think Netflix' success is what is hurting Redbox? Are you willing to comment on what hurt consumer demand for their products in Q4? And does this make a Redbox partnership more or less likely?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm pretty confident that our success is not what's hurting Redbox, because DVDs were barely up for us. And I think the Redbox it was up 30% or something. So I think those are really unrelated issues. And of course, our streaming content is not the newest
componenttext: I'm pretty confident that our success is not what's hurting Redbox, because DVDs were barely up for us. And I think the Redbox it was up 30% or something. So I think those are really unrelated issues. And of course, our streaming content is not the newest DVD releases and that's what Redbox focuses on, is the newest DVD releases. But I don't really have more to say than that about Redbox. You also asked, does that make a partnership more or less likely. I don't think it was ever that likely. We are super focused on streaming and unlimited streaming. They're focused on new release DVD and they do a great job at what they do.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question from Steven Frankel at Dougherty. What's the timing on introducing the Facebook innovation?
componenttext: Next question from Steven Frankel at Dougherty. What's the timing on introducing the Facebook innovation?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll be rolling that out in phases over this year, sort of quarter-by-quarter and month-by-month it will get better and better and better.
componenttext: We'll be rolling that out in phases over this year, sort of quarter-by-quarter and month-by-month it will get better and better and better.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And second question from Steven Frankel, at 20 million subscribers and growing, you have the scale to compete head-to-head with the traditional pay-TV services for first-run movies. As the studio deals with HBO and others expire, is that likely that Netfl
componenttext: And second question from Steven Frankel, at 20 million subscribers and growing, you have the scale to compete head-to-head with the traditional pay-TV services for first-run movies. As the studio deals with HBO and others expire, is that likely that Netflix competes for titles on an exclusive basis?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: It certainly is possible that we would compete on an exclusive basis. We're willing to do that if we have to. But we think it can make more economic sense for us and pay television to share windows conceptually, each paying 2/3 and the studio getting 1 1/
componenttext: It certainly is possible that we would compete on an exclusive basis. We're willing to do that if we have to. But we think it can make more economic sense for us and pay television to share windows conceptually, each paying 2/3 and the studio getting 1 1/3 of what they're getting in the past. So we tend to try to look for deals like that to make the content owners more money, and allow the other aggregators to pay a little less. But we're basically very flexible and just trying to find good ways to expand the content.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: From Michael Olson at Piper Jaffray, where will most of the OpEx for international fall? Will it be in marketing for the Netflix brands that is less well known?
componenttext: From Michael Olson at Piper Jaffray, where will most of the OpEx for international fall? Will it be in marketing for the Netflix brands that is less well known?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mike, this is David. I'd say that you can roughly -- I think, what we said in the past is that each international investment is split largely between marketing and streaming content and that will hold in the future.
componenttext: Mike, this is David. I'd say that you can roughly -- I think, what we said in the past is that each international investment is split largely between marketing and streaming content and that will hold in the future.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Barton Crockett at Lazard regarding international expansion. When you look at countries to expand into, do you see any desirable countries with meaningful incumbent providers of online subscription streaming services that you'd have
componenttext: Next question is from Barton Crockett at Lazard regarding international expansion. When you look at countries to expand into, do you see any desirable countries with meaningful incumbent providers of online subscription streaming services that you'd have to compete with? How does competition and the risk of losing Battle factor into your choice of countries to enter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Barton, as you would expect it's one of the factors. Typically in the markets that are the biggest prize, already there's vigorous competition and so it's a trade-off there. So we'll try a variety of things over the years both in markets that already have
componenttext: Barton, as you would expect it's one of the factors. Typically in the markets that are the biggest prize, already there's vigorous competition and so it's a trade-off there. So we'll try a variety of things over the years both in markets that already have competitors, also in the markets that don't of the type that you're describing. So I'd say, we tend to try to put our money in play, where we think it's got the best chance of a big sustainable return. And as I mentioned earlier to Ingrid, there's a lot of factors that go into that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jim Friedland at Cowen. Are you using AWS in Canada? Will you be able to use AWS in future international launches?
componenttext: The next question is from Jim Friedland at Cowen. Are you using AWS in Canada? Will you be able to use AWS in future international launches?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. AWS is very global already, and we'll continue to use AWS.
componenttext: Sure. AWS is very global already, and we'll continue to use AWS.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Ken Johnson, an individual investor. What is your perspective on national growth in non-English speaking markets? Would Netflix consider licensing a significant amount of non-english content of streaming to countries like India and/o
componenttext: Next question is from Ken Johnson, an individual investor. What is your perspective on national growth in non-English speaking markets? Would Netflix consider licensing a significant amount of non-english content of streaming to countries like India and/or China, perhaps the Spanish-speaking world?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. We don't limit ourselves in terms of our circle of competence to English-language content. In fact, we're a very big licensor of foreign content already for the U.S. market. And we feel very comfortable licensing content for a variety of cultures an
componenttext: Sure. We don't limit ourselves in terms of our circle of competence to English-language content. In fact, we're a very big licensor of foreign content already for the U.S. market. And we feel very comfortable licensing content for a variety of cultures and tastes. And really, it's our global process knowledge and our technology that's globally relevant. And by technology, I mean both on the streaming side and on the merchandising or matching, which people tend to like which titles.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. We estimate Netflix' domestic sales will surpass through HBO in 2012. Ted Sarandos recently suggested that Netflix would aggressively bid for Warner Bros content. And Warner's current arrangement with
componenttext: Next question is from Scott Devitt at Morgan Stanley. We estimate Netflix' domestic sales will surpass through HBO in 2012. Ted Sarandos recently suggested that Netflix would aggressively bid for Warner Bros content. And Warner's current arrangement with HBO expired in 2014. Given that HBO and Warner Bros. are owned by the same parent, a parent that has made several negative public comments about your business, could you explain the dynamics here and how it is possible that by bidding for the content, you could either get it or force HBO to pay more for it?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not sure I agree on the negative-comments aspect. The press makes a living out of blowing some things up, and we're nearly $100 million a year customer for Warner Bros, and both of us would like to expand that, if it makes sense to. In terms of
componenttext: Well, I'm not sure I agree on the negative-comments aspect. The press makes a living out of blowing some things up, and we're nearly $100 million a year customer for Warner Bros, and both of us would like to expand that, if it makes sense to. In terms of specifically bidding on the Warner Bros. content, that may be advantageous for us and maybe that we end up again doing a share, where Warner Bros. makes more money than they would have otherwise and both HBO and us have content, it could be a range of options in that. And clearly, they will make a strategic decision based upon the different interests of the different divisions, but they're quite comfortable having us bid on it. They're not trying to exclude us in any way.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Tony Wible at Janney Montgomery Scott. Do you believe that the move to variable-based distribution cost i.e. the FCC usage-base billing that has prompted some ISPs to consider tolling web-service companies, and the push to price
componenttext: The next question is from Tony Wible at Janney Montgomery Scott. Do you believe that the move to variable-based distribution cost i.e. the FCC usage-base billing that has prompted some ISPs to consider tolling web-service companies, and the push to price content on a variable basis will fundamentally change the way Netflix prices or tiers its service.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Tony, it's a risk, particularly if pay-per-gigabyte, pay-a-dollar-per-gigabyte type model for ISPs took hold. And so we will be involved in that debate. And again, since the cost of delivering a gigabyte are less than a $0.01 and falling, we don't t
componenttext: Well, Tony, it's a risk, particularly if pay-per-gigabyte, pay-a-dollar-per-gigabyte type model for ISPs took hold. And so we will be involved in that debate. And again, since the cost of delivering a gigabyte are less than a $0.01 and falling, we don't think it's terribly likely, but we don't want to be asleep at the switch and just let it happen.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Second question from Tony. Do you expect Google, Amazon and/or Apple to be a more formidable competitor in 2011?
componenttext: Second question from Tony. Do you expect Google, Amazon and/or Apple to be a more formidable competitor in 2011?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Definitely, there's a lot of firms, including the ones you mentioned that could be more direct competitor with us. The internet is creating a ton of opportunity for a lot of firms and there's all different models between the pay-per-view models for new re
componenttext: Definitely, there's a lot of firms, including the ones you mentioned that could be more direct competitor with us. The internet is creating a ton of opportunity for a lot of firms and there's all different models between the pay-per-view models for new releases, the ad-supported model. So there's a lot of different companies with different strengths. But as you know, we've been through a lot of competition in the past. We view that as a natural part of the process and we're just focused on building our business as best as we can.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is from John Blackledge at Crdit Suisse. What was the decline in disk shipments per subscriber per month in Q4 on a year-over-year basis. I think in Q3, disk shipments were down 24% year-over-year. Just wondering if the declines were a
componenttext: The next question is from John Blackledge at Crdit Suisse. What was the decline in disk shipments per subscriber per month in Q4 on a year-over-year basis. I think in Q3, disk shipments were down 24% year-over-year. Just wondering if the declines were around the same level or accelerating?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: John, we don't publish shipment information like that. I'm not sure where you got the Q3 quote. What we said in the letter and, I'll remind you is, disk shipments did actually continue to grow, they just grew a lower rate than we expected. And going into
componenttext: John, we don't publish shipment information like that. I'm not sure where you got the Q3 quote. What we said in the letter and, I'll remind you is, disk shipments did actually continue to grow, they just grew a lower rate than we expected. And going into the fourth quarter, we already knew that we're going to offer a price change and a new plan offering on the streaming-only plan starting in late November. There was some uncertainty around the take rate on that plan and how that would affect our disk shipments. And so we were a little bit conservative in terms of planning out the number of shipments and I think you see that reflected in lower shipments.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Nat Schindler at BofA Merrill. The comments in the text about charging for multiple streams per account is somewhat confusing to me. Are you planning to only limit the $7.99 plan to a single stream? Or are you expecting to limit
componenttext: The next question is from Nat Schindler at BofA Merrill. The comments in the text about charging for multiple streams per account is somewhat confusing to me. Are you planning to only limit the $7.99 plan to a single stream? Or are you expecting to limit all plans to a single stream at a time?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Both the $9.99 1-out DVD and the $7.99 are one stream at the time. And the vast majority of subscribers are on one of those two plans. So you could think of it as a vast majority of subscribers are on a one-stream at a time plan. So as we develop models a
componenttext: Both the $9.99 1-out DVD and the $7.99 are one stream at the time. And the vast majority of subscribers are on one of those two plans. So you could think of it as a vast majority of subscribers are on a one-stream at a time plan. So as we develop models around upgrades and how do you get either multiple streams on an account or multiple accounts or subaccounts, those are the kinds of things that we'll be testing and evolving over the coming quarters.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Justin Patterson at Morgan Keegan. With regard to your experience in Canada, how is the tracking versus your initial expectations? What's been your biggest challenge in the region? What lessons have you learned that you can take
componenttext: The next question is from Justin Patterson at Morgan Keegan. With regard to your experience in Canada, how is the tracking versus your initial expectations? What's been your biggest challenge in the region? What lessons have you learned that you can take to additional international markets?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the main lesson we've learned is confidence in the model. We were really unclear as to how well and aggressively priced on-demand Internet service would work. Without all the DVD and brand history, could we get a cost-efficient marketing and get s
componenttext: I think the main lesson we've learned is confidence in the model. We were really unclear as to how well and aggressively priced on-demand Internet service would work. Without all the DVD and brand history, could we get a cost-efficient marketing and get subscribers to sign up? And in fact, we've proven ourselves that at least within the conditions in Canada that, that is indeed very possible, and we've been very happy with the growth. And so then we'll take on a little bit bigger challenge and we've learned mostly to have confidence in the model of on-demand streaming.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Michael Pachter at Wedbush Securities. How long do you expect fixed-price contracts to be offered? Do you foresee a migration to a cost per subscriber model much as is used by cable companies in dealing with content providers?
componenttext: Next question is from Michael Pachter at Wedbush Securities. How long do you expect fixed-price contracts to be offered? Do you foresee a migration to a cost per subscriber model much as is used by cable companies in dealing with content providers?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Michael, that's a possibility but it's not very likely. I think what is happening is the contracts -- some of the contracts are short, a year or two. And so you can think of fixed cost for a year or two is really just a high granularity variable contract
componenttext: Michael, that's a possibility but it's not very likely. I think what is happening is the contracts -- some of the contracts are short, a year or two. And so you can think of fixed cost for a year or two is really just a high granularity variable contract based upon the size. And so, I would guess that it would go that way. We definitely agree with the model that as we grow bigger, any individual piece of content is more valuable to us and we'll end up paying more for it. But I think the form will be upon renewals of shorter-term deals.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question from Youssef Squali at Jefferies. Could you speak to net neutrality in Europe?
componenttext: Next question from Youssef Squali at Jefferies. Could you speak to net neutrality in Europe?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Youssef, net neutrality is a pretty strong concept in Europe. So no, no significant risks there. The aspect of the open regional, no charges interchange, however, is less strongly accepted, and that's probably the big issue, which is can ISPs charge conte
componenttext: Youssef, net neutrality is a pretty strong concept in Europe. So no, no significant risks there. The aspect of the open regional, no charges interchange, however, is less strongly accepted, and that's probably the big issue, which is can ISPs charge content providers like YouTube and Netflix and Amazon, a significant fee to serve their customers? And so that's probably where that interest and the friction will be?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question from Peter Treadway at EMS Capital. What do you think the operating margin potential of the company is at maturity? How do you think about the range of outcomes?
componenttext: Next question from Peter Treadway at EMS Capital. What do you think the operating margin potential of the company is at maturity? How do you think about the range of outcomes?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Peter, in prior calls, what I've said is the long term even maturity operating margins in an industry are really determined by the number of competitors. So if there's three or four roughly equal-sized competitors at maturity, you'd expect pretty low oper
componenttext: Peter, in prior calls, what I've said is the long term even maturity operating margins in an industry are really determined by the number of competitors. So if there's three or four roughly equal-sized competitors at maturity, you'd expect pretty low operating margins. If there's one firm that's the leading firm in the market, you'd expect higher operating margins. So it really depends upon the competitive climate as supposed to something inherent in the cost structure.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Andy Hargreaves at Pacific Crest Securities. As your subscriber base grows and subs stream more content, are you concerned about running into the limits of total bandwidth availability in a given geography?
componenttext: The next question is from Andy Hargreaves at Pacific Crest Securities. As your subscriber base grows and subs stream more content, are you concerned about running into the limits of total bandwidth availability in a given geography?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Oh, gosh. Not at all. We recently did a calculation about fiber optics and what we discovered is that a single fiber optic, about the size of a human hair, because of the advances in dense weight division multiplexing (sic) [dense wavelength division mult
componenttext: Oh, gosh. Not at all. We recently did a calculation about fiber optics and what we discovered is that a single fiber optic, about the size of a human hair, because of the advances in dense weight division multiplexing (sic) [dense wavelength division multiplexing] can now carry all 100% of the Netflix traffic. So if we had a single data center where all the bits came out of, it could comfortably go out in a single fiber. And furthermore, the improvements in the next three years expected in fiber optics are increasing that number. So I would say the rate of innovation in data transmission, especially on fiber, is greatly outstripping any growth that we could possibly get to.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is a follow-up question from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS, following up on the declining disc shipment question. In the letter you say, and that you expect disc shipments to decline year-over-year in the coming quarters. Is this the first time yo
componenttext: Next question is a follow-up question from Brian Fitzgerald at UBS, following up on the declining disc shipment question. In the letter you say, and that you expect disc shipments to decline year-over-year in the coming quarters. Is this the first time you pointed to this? Did you move this inflection point forward?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Brian, this is David. Yes, it is the first time that we've talked about this. And it's largely a function of plan mix, the streaming offer, streaming-only plan offering and just the embrace of the streaming-only offering service in general.
componenttext: Brian, this is David. Yes, it is the first time that we've talked about this. And it's largely a function of plan mix, the streaming offer, streaming-only plan offering and just the embrace of the streaming-only offering service in general.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's the last question I have. We'd like to thank everyone for your time, and we look forward to talking to you again next quarter.
componenttext: That's the last question I have. We'd like to thank everyone for your time, and we look forward to talking to you again next quarter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: This concludes the conference call. Have a great day.
componenttext: This concludes the conference call. Have a great day.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Netflix First Quarter 2011 Earnings Q&A Session. [Operator Instructions] At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Ellie, Vice President of Finance and Investor Relatio
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Netflix First Quarter 2011 Earnings Q&A Session. [Operator Instructions] At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Ellie, Vice President of Finance and Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix's 2011 Earnings Q&A Session. We now start our financial results for the first quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific time today. The shareholder letter and the Q1 financial results and the webcast
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix's 2011 Earnings Q&A Session. We now start our financial results for the first quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific time today. The shareholder letter and the Q1 financial results and the webcast of this Q&A session are all available at the company's Investor Relations website at ir.Netflix.com. As is our standard practice, this call will consist solely of Q&A and we're going to conduct the Q&A via e-mail. Please email your questions to IR@Netflix.com. 
We may make forward-looking statements during this call regarding the companies future performance. Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to risks and uncertainties related to the business. A detailed discussion of such risks and uncertainties is contained in our filings with Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the Commission on February 18, 2011. A rebroadcast of this Q&A session will be available at the Netflix website after 6:00 p.m. Pacific time today. 
Now let's move directly to questions. We've organized the questions by topic design, and I'll start with content questions. Here we go.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: As you acquire digital content, at what level of competition are you seeing during the negotiation?
componenttext: As you acquire digital content, at what level of competition are you seeing during the negotiation?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: There is a substantial level of competition, as you would expect, not only amongst the online players but against cable networks and sometimes, in partnership with cable networks in the window sharing. So content owners want to get the best price for thei
componenttext: There is a substantial level of competition, as you would expect, not only amongst the online players but against cable networks and sometimes, in partnership with cable networks in the window sharing. So content owners want to get the best price for their content and see what to expect, and they are pretty sophisticated about making sure that they have got all the possible offers on the table.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Related question, how much risk that Amazon will outbid for Netflix for digital rights to start of content?
componenttext: Related question, how much risk that Amazon will outbid for Netflix for digital rights to start of content?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure that Amazon specifically is a different of list, I would say, in general. The Star like any other content provider wants to get most money for their content. The Star's deal is not exclusive today so it could be across a range of providers, i
componenttext: I'm not sure that Amazon specifically is a different of list, I would say, in general. The Star like any other content provider wants to get most money for their content. The Star's deal is not exclusive today so it could be across a range of providers, it could be a single and I'm not particularly single Amazon as a risk factor relative to Dish or anybody else.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: In the past, Reed has commented about shutting down Red Envelope and that's just lack of interest in producing content, licensing previously on released content that on creativity and outside of Netflix's circle of confidence. How can you reconcile these
componenttext: In the past, Reed has commented about shutting down Red Envelope and that's just lack of interest in producing content, licensing previously on released content that on creativity and outside of Netflix's circle of confidence. How can you reconcile these previous remarks with the recent to moves invest in the recent House of Cards series?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, there is a slight shift there, which is we are willing to try a little bit more riskier work than we have done with a little bit of our budget and we're going to see how it goes. It's sort of how we approach international, when we tried Canada first
componenttext: Well, there is a slight shift there, which is we are willing to try a little bit more riskier work than we have done with a little bit of our budget and we're going to see how it goes. It's sort of how we approach international, when we tried Canada first before getting too committed. And our theory is that with serialized content, we may be able to build an audience very effectively because if you look at on-demand, if you can get back to the first episode as momentum around the series builds. I don't know what's anything that with the, on but we are certainly willing to try it with a small percent of the budget in House of Cards and then 2 to 3 other smaller ones that we would look for. And if we're successful with it, then we would expand our circle of confidence a little bit more, a little bit more. So we'll take it step-by-step at year-by-year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: To add to that, this is David. In the House of Cards deal. It was a prepackaged deal that came to us. We weren't looking for out there looking for creative talent or directors or script. It's a small new ones but it was an important 1 for us and the fact
componenttext: To add to that, this is David. In the House of Cards deal. It was a prepackaged deal that came to us. We weren't looking for out there looking for creative talent or directors or script. It's a small new ones but it was an important 1 for us and the fact that we weren't having managed for the larger part of the creative process.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: An additional question on House of Cards. Are you seeking divides in domestic or global rates to House of Cards. Is your intent to keep House of Cards exclusive to Netflix or  actually presenting the series on Netflix, will you look to sell subsequent len
componenttext: An additional question on House of Cards. Are you seeking divides in domestic or global rates to House of Cards. Is your intent to keep House of Cards exclusive to Netflix or  actually presenting the series on Netflix, will you look to sell subsequent lengths to other cable or broadcast networks or online services?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, House of Cards wouldn't  start until the fall of next year, so there'll be a couple years out before we are faced with those decisions and we've licensed it for multiple territories.
componenttext: Well, House of Cards wouldn't  start until the fall of next year, so there'll be a couple years out before we are faced with those decisions and we've licensed it for multiple territories.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Speculation future spend on Mad Men at nearly $1 million per episode, which seems to be lower than recent syndication deals or procedurals but higher deals for some other low serialized series. Why didn't just decide to pay for exclusivity? And shou
componenttext: Okay. Speculation future spend on Mad Men at nearly $1 million per episode, which seems to be lower than recent syndication deals or procedurals but higher deals for some other low serialized series. Why didn't just decide to pay for exclusivity? And should we think about your Mad Men deal as typical of some other deal as you maybe doing going forward or was it the unique case?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We don't comment on the specific deal terms of any of our deals.
componenttext: We don't comment on the specific deal terms of any of our deals.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you share any data that supports your view that putting a previous season on Netflix growth for audience for the current season of the show, wouldn't that also diminish sales prior to season DVDs?
componenttext: Can you share any data that supports your view that putting a previous season on Netflix growth for audience for the current season of the show, wouldn't that also diminish sales prior to season DVDs?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, what we've seen as an example with Spartacus is we have seen something even more aggressive, which is we have currencies in the Spartacus that's a Starz original, which has been very successful. And now, it won the highest rated shows on cable despi
componenttext: Well, what we've seen as an example with Spartacus is we have seen something even more aggressive, which is we have currencies in the Spartacus that's a Starz original, which has been very successful. And now, it won the highest rated shows on cable despite the fact or maybe because of the fact that it is also on Netflix. And so, I think, in general, it's opened our eyes to the fact that more and more awareness of a given show sometimes creates more viewing on both cable and our DVD and on Netflix.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Given the size of your subscriber base, is it getting easier to negotiate content deals or is still at level of animosity with some content of others that must still be worked through?
componenttext: Given the size of your subscriber base, is it getting easier to negotiate content deals or is still at level of animosity with some content of others that must still be worked through?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't think there's any animosity. It's only a question of is our check big enough until we get a larger subscriber base that becomes easier to write bigger checks? And it's very respectful, I would say across the board.
componenttext: I don't think there's any animosity. It's only a question of is our check big enough until we get a larger subscriber base that becomes easier to write bigger checks? And it's very respectful, I would say across the board.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Moving to the topic of international. In terms of international expansion and in content acquisition in non-U.S. markets, what type of expansion do you anticipate locally relevant content and how those deals concern the outlook on different domestic deals
componenttext: Moving to the topic of international. In terms of international expansion and in content acquisition in non-U.S. markets, what type of expansion do you anticipate locally relevant content and how those deals concern the outlook on different domestic deals?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not sure of how much local content will be important for Netflix. With Canada, we've got a fair amount of Canadian content and it was successful for us. And our new territories will also license some local content and then we will feel our way a
componenttext: Well, I'm not sure of how much local content will be important for Netflix. With Canada, we've got a fair amount of Canadian content and it was successful for us. And our new territories will also license some local content and then we will feel our way along as we see next, what's our subscribers are doing and that what they enjoy.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'd say there's an opportunity here outside the U.S. in some markets. And with respect to some local content, there might not be a secondary market or a third or fourth sort of channel for the content owner. So to the extent that we might be the only synd
componenttext: I'd say there's an opportunity here outside the U.S. in some markets. And with respect to some local content, there might not be a secondary market or a third or fourth sort of channel for the content owner. So to the extent that we might be the only syndicated buyer in the market, it's going to work well for us in terms of economics.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think you should think about them as separate. You all run the U.S. around 14% operating margin and spend on content in accordance with that. And in international, you'll spend as we see appropriate to launch service, where we got spending ahead of reve
componenttext: I think you should think about them as separate. You all run the U.S. around 14% operating margin and spend on content in accordance with that. And in international, you'll spend as we see appropriate to launch service, where we got spending ahead of revenue. And then as rapidly as possible, within the quarters of our target model that each territory should be positive operating margin. In Canada, we've been very successful and we intend to be breakeven on our operating contribution basis within 4 quarters of launch which is in Q3 and really quite extraordinary. That's probably too high a bar for every international territory but 8 quarters feels good.

componenttext: We don't have any indication that in the U.S., low, call it, below 100 gigabytes data caps are going to become a significant offering. In Canada, it's sort of a default so every virtually everybody is on our low data usage, slightly lower video quality plan. And it is helping both directly in terms of the usage and indirectly in terms of general fear of usage charges, so it's a mitigator. I'm not sure I would call it a solution. It helps, I think, the right solution overtime if the Canadians enjoy great untapped Internet like the rest of the developed world.

componenttext: Well, what we said before was that the individual subscriber market is that 2 to 3 or few year I think is how we characterize it in the last Investor Letter. And we haven't changed our point of view. This is the gradual revolution. It's not going to be an immediate 90- or 180-day thing for Netflix. And, I think, pricing is certainly part of that evolution, changes to the interfaces part of that evolution, changes to how we if and when we enforce concurrent to your device or by high account. So there's a lot of things for us to figure out and out. We wouldn't want to alienate the subscriber or the consumer as we get through those. And I think we'll evolve to those over the next couple of years.

componenttext: Well, given how stable churn has been for the next 2 years, the hard put have been quiet should suddenly decline in the next 18 months. And the question refers to us like other MVPD, and  MVPD  is a much different service. It's premise based. Its more expensive and it's more considered a retention service so it's really just quite different in all those dimensions. We have a low subscriber acquisition cost and we have higher churn. And people do test out the service, come back, go out, go in and because more overall growth our net adds are continuing to increase.

componenttext: There is this white day going forward but what we said in the last quarters in the investor letter and we reiterated it in this Investor Letter is that we identify the fact that we would have additional money. We would love to spend it on streaming content because of the complexity of those contracts, there's more lead time acquired and therefore, we put the money into marketing. So the higher stack sequentially from Q4 to Q1 is a somewhat of an artifact of additional marketing dollars we spent up to the efficient point in Q1. And we'll continue to make that trade-off going forward. Now what we've said in the Investor Letter just to remind folks is that we're going to weigh streaming cost. We plan to do that. We're going to continue to do that and so you should see marketing as a percentage of revenue somewhat nullified but relative to Q1.

We comment of all that notion to believe that that's not necessarily the case especially with a streaming product that we've watched nationally. So in terms of penetration, that's 21% U.S.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Moving on to questions about the financials. In response to your question as of last quarter regarding the significant increase in AT, the company indicated that "largely payment are having short timing at the end of the quarter that could reverse itself
componenttext: Moving on to questions about the financials. In response to your question as of last quarter regarding the significant increase in AT, the company indicated that "largely payment are having short timing at the end of the quarter that could reverse itself in Q1" Can the company indicate why did this not reverse in Q1 and instead AP increased further?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: So I was just responding to you the is the sequential increase in AP last quarter. I answered it somewhat narrowly in saying that the two contrast I've observed the increase are going to reverse themselves out in Q2 and they did. On top of that, in additi
componenttext: So I was just responding to you the is the sequential increase in AP last quarter. I answered it somewhat narrowly in saying that the two contrast I've observed the increase are going to reverse themselves out in Q2 and they did. On top of that, in addition to that, we signed a bunch of new content deals that we discussed in the Investor Letter. And to the extent that those deals were within a year with identified titles, it drove the APL. So let me answer it in a general sense. Cash payments for content increased $130 million year-over-year versus $110 million year-over-year increase in the expense associated with that content. So to the extent that we talked about close to matching our payment terms with our expense, we are continuing to execute on that. We ran a little bit ahead in Q1. In terms of the sequential increase, the cash out of outdoor content was roughly in line with the expense increase. So I think, you should see the accounts payable and the associated long-term accrued payable line increased with our continued investment in streaming content. I don't think you'll see it increase of quite a same rate say, going forward as you saw in the last couple of quarters but it will go up.

componenttext: And I think we're doing both. I think we're trying to draw a fine distinction between being a pure company that invests everything we possibly have into growth and also returning some to shareholders. So I think it's consistent with the strategy that we've had for quite some time trying to draw both, to do both, being a growth company and make sure that we are not setting up a false promise to return earnings down the road.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Moving to a marketing question. You know exactly a what is likely to be a very lucrative out front process for both broadcast and Cable Networks come this May and June? Do you see it paying to possibly be as high as to low teens price hikes for the networ
componenttext: Moving to a marketing question. You know exactly a what is likely to be a very lucrative out front process for both broadcast and Cable Networks come this May and June? Do you see it paying to possibly be as high as to low teens price hikes for the network and inventory, network add inventory to marketing purposes? Or do you just bypass network television spending and carrier marketing spend more so towards a more alternative such as outdoor  and radio?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We always try to market most efficiently we can and sometimes if 1 channel say, outdoor or online or on print or network when increasing costs, it would get less of our total dollars. So it's a big broad mix of the 2 primary components for us online. And
componenttext: We always try to market most efficiently we can and sometimes if 1 channel say, outdoor or online or on print or network when increasing costs, it would get less of our total dollars. So it's a big broad mix of the 2 primary components for us online. And television not necessarily network but cable.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: All right. Okay, so that's the last question for today. We would like to thank everyone for your time and we look forward to speaking to you again next quarter.
componenttext: All right. Okay, so that's the last question for today. We would like to thank everyone for your time and we look forward to speaking to you again next quarter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, everyone.
componenttext: Thanks, everyone.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. this does concludes today's program. Thank you for your participation and have a wonderful day. Attendees, you may now disconnect.
componenttext: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. this does concludes today's program. Thank you for your participation and have a wonderful day. Attendees, you may now disconnect.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Netflix First Quarter 2011 Earnings Q&A Session. [Operator Instructions] At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the call over to Ellie Mertz, Vice President of Finance and Investor Relat
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Netflix First Quarter 2011 Earnings Q&A Session. [Operator Instructions] At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the call over to Ellie Mertz, Vice President of Finance and Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix 2011 Earnings Q&A Session. We now start our financial results for the first quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific Time today. The shareholder letter and the Q1 financial results and the webcast of
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix 2011 Earnings Q&A Session. We now start our financial results for the first quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific Time today. The shareholder letter and the Q1 financial results and the webcast of this Q&A session are all available at the company's Investor Relations website at ir.netflix.com. 
As is our standard practice, this call will consist solely of Q&A, and we're going to conduct the Q&A via e-mail. Please email your questions to ir@netflix.com. 
We may make forward-looking statements during this call regarding the company's future performance. Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to risks and uncertainties related to the business. A detailed discussion of such risks and uncertainties is contained in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the Commission on February 18, 2011. A rebroadcast of this Q&A session will be available at the Netflix website after 6:00 p.m. Pacific Time today. 
Now let's move directly to questions. We've organized the questions by topic design, and we'll start with content questions. Here we go.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: As you acquire digital content rights, what level of competition are you seeing during the negotiation?
componenttext: As you acquire digital content rights, what level of competition are you seeing during the negotiation?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's a substantial level of competition, as you would expect, not only amongst the online players but against cable networks and sometimes in partnership with cable networks in the window sharing. So content owners want to get the best price for their
componenttext: There's a substantial level of competition, as you would expect, not only amongst the online players but against cable networks and sometimes in partnership with cable networks in the window sharing. So content owners want to get the best price for their content as you would expect, and they're pretty sophisticated about making sure that they've got all the possible offers on the table.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Related question, how much risk is there that Amazon will outbid for Netflix for digital rights to Starz content?
componenttext: Related question, how much risk is there that Amazon will outbid for Netflix for digital rights to Starz content?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure that Amazon specifically is a different list. I would say, in general, Starz, like any other content provider wants to get the most money for their content. The Starz deal is non-exclusive today so it could be across a range of providers, it
componenttext: I'm not sure that Amazon specifically is a different list. I would say, in general, Starz, like any other content provider wants to get the most money for their content. The Starz deal is non-exclusive today so it could be across a range of providers, it could be a single. But I don't think I'd particularly single Amazon as a risk factor relative to [indiscernible] (12:02) Dish or anybody else.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: In the past, Reed has commented about shutting down Red Envelope and that it's lack of interest in producing content or licensing previously unreleased content that they've got on creativity and was outside of Netflix's circle of confidence. How can you r
componenttext: In the past, Reed has commented about shutting down Red Envelope and that it's lack of interest in producing content or licensing previously unreleased content that they've got on creativity and was outside of Netflix's circle of confidence. How can you reconcile these previous remarks with the recent move to invest in the recent House of Cards series?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, there is a slight shift there, which is we're willing to try a little bit more riskier work than we've done with a little bit of our budget, and then we're going to see how it goes. So sort of how we approach international, when we tried Canada firs
componenttext: Well, there is a slight shift there, which is we're willing to try a little bit more riskier work than we've done with a little bit of our budget, and then we're going to see how it goes. So sort of how we approach international, when we tried Canada first before getting too committed. And our theory is that with serialized content, we may be able to build an audience very effectively because if you look at on-demand, you can get back to the first episode as momentum around the series builds. I don't know if it's anything we'd bet the farm on, but we're certainly willing to try it with a small percent of the budget in House of Cards and then 2 to 3 other smaller ones that we would look for. And if we're successful with it, then we would expand our circle of confidence a little bit more, a little bit more. So we'll take it step-by-step and year-by-year.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: To add to that, this is David. In the House of Cards deal, it was a prepackaged deal that came to us. We weren't looking for -- out there looking for creative talent or directors or a script. It's a small nuance, but it was an important one for us and the
componenttext: To add to that, this is David. In the House of Cards deal, it was a prepackaged deal that came to us. We weren't looking for -- out there looking for creative talent or directors or a script. It's a small nuance, but it was an important one for us and the fact that we weren't having managed a the larger part of the creative process.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: An additional question on House of Cards. Are you seeking to buy domestic or global rates to House of Cards? Is your intent to keep House of Cards exclusive to Netflix? Or  actually presenting the series on Netflix, will you look to sell subsequent length
componenttext: An additional question on House of Cards. Are you seeking to buy domestic or global rates to House of Cards? Is your intent to keep House of Cards exclusive to Netflix? Or  actually presenting the series on Netflix, will you look to sell subsequent lengths to other cable or broadcast networks or online services?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, House of Cards doesn't start until the fall of next year so it'll be a couple years out before we are faced with those decisions, and we've licensed it for multiple territories.
componenttext: Well, House of Cards doesn't start until the fall of next year so it'll be a couple years out before we are faced with those decisions, and we've licensed it for multiple territories.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Press speculation puts your spend on Mad Men at nearly $1 million per episode, which seems to be lower than recent syndication deals for procedurals, but higher deals for some other low profile, serialized series. Why didn't you just decide to pay f
componenttext: Okay. Press speculation puts your spend on Mad Men at nearly $1 million per episode, which seems to be lower than recent syndication deals for procedurals, but higher deals for some other low profile, serialized series. Why didn't you just decide to pay for exclusivity? And should we think of your Mad Men deal as typical of some other TV deals you may be doing going forward or was it the unique case?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We don't comment on the specific deal terms of any of our deals.
componenttext: We don't comment on the specific deal terms of any of our deals.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you share any data that supports your view that putting a previous season on Netflix grows audience for a current season of the show? Wouldn't Netflix also diminish sales of prior season DVDs?
componenttext: Can you share any data that supports your view that putting a previous season on Netflix grows audience for a current season of the show? Wouldn't Netflix also diminish sales of prior season DVDs?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, what we've seen as an example with Spartacus is we've seen something even more aggressive, which is we have currencies in the Spartacus that's a Starz original, which has been very successful. And now, it's one of the highest rated shows on cable de
componenttext: Well, what we've seen as an example with Spartacus is we've seen something even more aggressive, which is we have currencies in the Spartacus that's a Starz original, which has been very successful. And now, it's one of the highest rated shows on cable despite the fact or maybe because of the fact that it's also on Netflix. And so I think, in general, it's opened our eyes to the fact that more and more awareness of a given show sometimes creates more viewing on both cable and our MVPD [multichannel video programming distributor] and on Netflix.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Given the size of your subscriber base, is it getting easier to negotiate content deals or is there still a level of animosity with some content owners that must be worked through?
componenttext: Given the size of your subscriber base, is it getting easier to negotiate content deals or is there still a level of animosity with some content owners that must be worked through?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't think there's any animosity. It's only a question of is our check big enough. As we get a larger subscriber base, that becomes easier to write bigger checks. And it's very respectful, I would say, across the board.
componenttext: I don't think there's any animosity. It's only a question of is our check big enough. As we get a larger subscriber base, that becomes easier to write bigger checks. And it's very respectful, I would say, across the board.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Moving to the topic of international. In terms of international expansion and content acquisition in non-U.S. markets, what type of expansion do you anticipate for locally relevant content, and how might deals with foreign outlets differ from domestic dea
componenttext: Moving to the topic of international. In terms of international expansion and content acquisition in non-U.S. markets, what type of expansion do you anticipate for locally relevant content, and how might deals with foreign outlets differ from domestic deals?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not sure of how much local content will be important for Netflix. With Canada, we've got a fair amount of Canadian content and it's quite successful for us. And our new territories will also license some local content, and then we'll feel our wa
componenttext: Well, I'm not sure of how much local content will be important for Netflix. With Canada, we've got a fair amount of Canadian content and it's quite successful for us. And our new territories will also license some local content, and then we'll feel our way along as we see what's our subscribers are viewing and that what they enjoy.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'd say there's an opportunity here outside the U.S. in some markets. And with respect to some local content, there might not be a secondary market or a third or fourth sort of channel for the content owner. So to the extent that we might be the only synd
componenttext: I'd say there's an opportunity here outside the U.S. in some markets. And with respect to some local content, there might not be a secondary market or a third or fourth sort of channel for the content owner. So to the extent that we might be the only syndicated buyer in the market, it's going to work well for us in terms of the economics.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Will new geographies take priority over the U.S. as you build out content? Or should we continue to expect the U.S. to see the bulk of the spending?
componenttext: Will new geographies take priority over the U.S. as you build out content? Or should we continue to expect the U.S. to see the bulk of the spending?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think you should think about them as separate. We'll all run the U.S. around 14% operating margin and spend on content in accordance with that. And in international, you'll spend as we see appropriate to launch the service, where we got to spending ahea
componenttext: I think you should think about them as separate. We'll all run the U.S. around 14% operating margin and spend on content in accordance with that. And in international, you'll spend as we see appropriate to launch the service, where we got to spending ahead of revenue. And then as rapidly as possible, within 8 quarters of our target model that each territory to be positive operating margin. In Canada, we've been very successful and we intend to be breakeven on our operating contribution basis within 4 quarters of launch which is in Q3 and really quite extraordinary. That's probably too high a bar for every international territory, but 8 quarters feels good.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the topic of Canada, can you provide a little color on how the ISP bandwidth cap in Canada have impacted consumer behavior? What percentage of your Canadian customers are using the new "managed video quality tool" in watching lower quality video? Also
componenttext: On the topic of Canada, can you provide a little color on how the ISP bandwidth cap in Canada have impacted consumer behavior? What percentage of your Canadian customers are using the new "managed video quality tool" in watching lower quality video? Also do you believe ISPs in the U.S. or other countries are thinking of capping bandwidth in a similar strict fashion?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We don't have any indication that in the U.S. low, call it, below 100 gigabytes data caps are going to become a significant offering. In Canada, it's switched to default so every virtually everybody is on our low data usage, slightly lower video quality p
componenttext: We don't have any indication that in the U.S. low, call it, below 100 gigabytes data caps are going to become a significant offering. In Canada, it's switched to default so every virtually everybody is on our low data usage, slightly lower video quality plan. And it is helping both directly in terms of the usage and indirectly in terms of the general fear of usage charges, so it's a mitigator. I'm not sure I would call it a solution. It helps. I think, the right solution, over time, is that Canadians enjoy great untapped Internet like the rest of the developed world.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Related question, how do usage patterns in Canada perform relative to your expectation given the various cap rates? What share of the more modest subscriber growth performance relative to your expectations?
componenttext: Related question, how do usage patterns in Canada perform relative to your expectation given the various cap rates? What share of the more modest subscriber growth performance relative to your expectations?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think on what drove the overshoot on the forecast is just we don't have any seasonal data. So the growth was very consistent throughout the quarter, and we're really happy with it. And it's a pretty small percentage, but we just don't have multiple year
componenttext: I think on what drove the overshoot on the forecast is just we don't have any seasonal data. So the growth was very consistent throughout the quarter, and we're really happy with it. And it's a pretty small percentage, but we just don't have multiple years of year-on-year data. In terms of the caps, they play a role but, they played a role from inception. The caps are not something that were new this quarter. The caps have been in effect for a year or more in Canada.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just to add to that, we achieved 8% of bargain household penetration in Canada in 7 months. It took us 6 years in the U.S. to get there. Just so that you don't feel like we're sort of trying to makes ourselves feel better on the forecasting is we're happy
componenttext: Just to add to that, we achieved 8% of bargain household penetration in Canada in 7 months. It took us 6 years in the U.S. to get there. Just so that you don't feel like we're sort of trying to makes ourselves feel better on the forecasting is we're happy about the business. We think we got a great business going in Canada and we're excited about going forward.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Another related question. The shareholder letter mentioned the seasonality curve in Canada. Can you elaborate on this comment? Is your initial sense that the markets similar to other colder regions, the subscriber growth is more tepid in the warm months?
componenttext: Another related question. The shareholder letter mentioned the seasonality curve in Canada. Can you elaborate on this comment? Is your initial sense that the markets similar to other colder regions, the subscriber growth is more tepid in the warm months?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll know year and year and a half from now after we've gone through the initial seasonality is massed by the launch. And so you really can't get a clean read until at least a year from now about the beginnings of the seasonality effect.
componenttext: We'll know year and year and a half from now after we've gone through the initial seasonality is massed by the launch. And so you really can't get a clean read until at least a year from now about the beginnings of the seasonality effect.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Is it reasonable to assume that Netflix could enter as many as two international markets or more per year starting in 2012?
componenttext: Is it reasonable to assume that Netflix could enter as many as two international markets or more per year starting in 2012?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: If we continue to see the kind of success that we've seen in Canada, if we think it would be very smart for us to move at least that fast, yes.
componenttext: If we continue to see the kind of success that we've seen in Canada, if we think it would be very smart for us to move at least that fast, yes.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: You noted a high probability of success in our second international market, driving early content commitments for our third market  What are the data points that you focus us on to define success prior to launching in a market?
componenttext: You noted a high probability of success in our second international market, driving early content commitments for our third market  What are the data points that you focus us on to define success prior to launching in a market?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: The reason that we feel a high degree of confidence is how well Canada has done, how well our licensing has gone for content in our second international market, and our qualitative focus group worked on the reactions in that market for our service. So tho
componenttext: The reason that we feel a high degree of confidence is how well Canada has done, how well our licensing has gone for content in our second international market, and our qualitative focus group worked on the reactions in that market for our service. So those are all very healthy indicators that we'll enjoy success.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And those qualitative factors have a lot to do with how much that content is going to cost us relative to where we think we could price it and the consumers' willingness to pay based on their other entertainment alternatives. And we've grown more, I think
componenttext: And those qualitative factors have a lot to do with how much that content is going to cost us relative to where we think we could price it and the consumers' willingness to pay based on their other entertainment alternatives. And we've grown more, I think, confident over the last year given where we think those economics are going to work out.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Moving to the topic of subscribers and subscriber metrics. Do you think we'll get tiered pricing from multiuser households from Netflix by year end? In that case, how big an addressable market is it?
componenttext: Moving to the topic of subscribers and subscriber metrics. Do you think we'll get tiered pricing from multiuser households from Netflix by year end? In that case, how big an addressable market is it?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, what we said before was that the individual subscriber market is that 2 to 3 or few year, I think is how we characterized it in the last Investor Letter. And we haven't changed our point of view. This is a gradual evolution. It's not going to be an
componenttext: Well, what we said before was that the individual subscriber market is that 2 to 3 or few year, I think is how we characterized it in the last Investor Letter. And we haven't changed our point of view. This is a gradual evolution. It's not going to be an immediate 90- or 180-day thing for Netflix. And I think pricing is certainly part of that evolution, changes to the interface is part of that evolution, changes to how we -- if and when we enforce concurrent stream limit per device or by account. So there's a lot of things for us to figure out and tease out. We wouldn't want to alienate the subscriber or the consumer as we go through those. And I think that we'll evolve to those over the next couple of years.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you share any details on safe port [ph] (23:01) integration that you are working on? What will be the primary objective of the same? Enhance your recommendation or driving the engagement or acquire subscribers?
componenttext: Can you share any details on safe port [ph] (23:01) integration that you are working on? What will be the primary objective of the same? Enhance your recommendation or driving the engagement or acquire subscribers?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's better for us to share those details when we launch that. So I'll defer that.
componenttext: It's better for us to share those details when we launch that. So I'll defer that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Are you starting to see DVD subscribers trade down from multi-op subscription?
componenttext: Are you starting to see DVD subscribers trade down from multi-op subscription?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. In fact, what we've said before is that basically downward migration and upward migration are canceling each other, and that's what we continue to see. With respect to the price change, we saw behavior that was more linked to the immedia
componenttext: I don't think so. In fact, what we've said before is that basically downward migration and upward migration are canceling each other, and that's what we continue to see. With respect to the price change, we saw behavior that was more linked to the immediate announcement than to the credit card change. Meaning when a subscriber actually got the change to the price on their bill, there wasn't as much activity as when they were notified of the change.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Related to the price increase. Was the price increase of contributor to the increase in churn or was it more of a normal seasonal pattern?
componenttext: Related to the price increase. Was the price increase of contributor to the increase in churn or was it more of a normal seasonal pattern?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Normal seasonal pattern. It's also a factor of the tremendous growth we saw in Q1. If you followed our company for a long time, you'll note that when we grow quickly, our churn goes up because the retention rates of early subscriber are lower than those s
componenttext: Normal seasonal pattern. It's also a factor of the tremendous growth we saw in Q1. If you followed our company for a long time, you'll note that when we grow quickly, our churn goes up because the retention rates of early subscriber are lower than those subscribers that have been around for 12 or more months. And we continue to see that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Another question on churn. Can you comment some on the churn rates for streaming-only customers in the U.S.? And is it above or below the average? Do you expect it to decline over time as customers are maybe testing out this service today?
componenttext: Another question on churn. Can you comment some on the churn rates for streaming-only customers in the U.S.? And is it above or below the average? Do you expect it to decline over time as customers are maybe testing out this service today?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: What we said is streaming only has a higher churn rate. It's easier to get in of and out of so it's the same as we said last quarter.
componenttext: What we said is streaming only has a higher churn rate. It's easier to get in of and out of so it's the same as we said last quarter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we've said before that the streaming-only plan actually crossed over the DVD only. So that is retention for streaming-only subscribers is actually a higher rate than DVD-only subscribers. It's going to be slightly lower than hybrid, but it's better.
componenttext: And we've said before that the streaming-only plan actually crossed over the DVD only. So that is retention for streaming-only subscribers is actually a higher rate than DVD-only subscribers. It's going to be slightly lower than hybrid, but it's better.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And the final question on churn. It still seems like the overall churn for the company is still high relative to other MVPD companies, and could you -- and caution you to respond tax dollars on customers that have already Netflix subscribers in the past?
componenttext: And the final question on churn. It still seems like the overall churn for the company is still high relative to other MVPD companies, and could you -- and caution you to respond tax dollars on customers that have already Netflix subscribers in the past? If your customer satisfaction is very high on your streaming products, shouldn't your churn materially decline over the next 18 months in the United States?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, given how stable churn has been the last 2 years, I'd be hard put be quiet should it suddenly decline in the next 18 months. And the question refers to us like other MVPD, and  MVPD is a much different service. It's premises-based. It's more expensi
componenttext: Well, given how stable churn has been the last 2 years, I'd be hard put be quiet should it suddenly decline in the next 18 months. And the question refers to us like other MVPD, and  MVPD is a much different service. It's premises-based. It's more expensive, and it's more considered an essential service so it's really just quite different in all those dimensions. We have a low subscriber acquisition cost, and we have higher churn. And people do test out the service, come back, go out, go in. And that's fine because our overall growth, our net adds are continuing to increase.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Moving to the topic of SAC [subscriber acquisition cost]. How did the domestic SAC rise so much quarter-over-quarter? Which should be the right base level going forward, Q4's 10 87? Or Q1's 14 38?
componenttext: Moving to the topic of SAC [subscriber acquisition cost]. How did the domestic SAC rise so much quarter-over-quarter? Which should be the right base level going forward, Q4's 10 87? Or Q1's 14 38?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's no such thing as a white day for going forward, but what we said in the last quarter's Investor Letter and we reiterate it in this Investor Letter is that we identified the fact that we would have additional money. We would love to spend it on str
componenttext: There's no such thing as a white day for going forward, but what we said in the last quarter's Investor Letter and we reiterate it in this Investor Letter is that we identified the fact that we would have additional money.
