Press speculation puts your spend on Mad Men at nearly $1 million per episode, which seems to be lower than recent syndication deals for procedurals, but higher than deals for some other low profile, serialized series. Why did you just decide to pay for exclusivity? And should we think of your Mad Men deal as typical of some other TV deals you may be doing going forward or was it the unique case?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We don't comment on the specific deal terms of any of our deals.
componenttext: We don't comment on the specific deal terms of any of our deals.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you share any data that supports your view that putting a previous season on Netflix grows audience for a current season of the show? Wouldn't Netflix also diminish sales of prior season DVDs?
componenttext: Can you share any data that supports your view that putting a previous season on Netflix grows audience for a current season of the show? Wouldn't Netflix also diminish sales of prior season DVDs?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, what we've seen as an example with Spartacus is we've seen something even more aggressive, which is we have current season with Spartacus, that's a Starz original, which has been very successful. And now, it's one of the highest rated shows on cable
componenttext: Well, what we've seen as an example with Spartacus is we've seen something even more aggressive, which is we have current season with Spartacus, that's a Starz original, which has been very successful. And now, it's one of the highest rated shows on cable despite the fact or maybe because of the fact that it's also on Netflix. And so I think, in general, it's opened our eyes to the fact that more and more awareness of a given show sometimes creates more viewing on both cable and our MVPD [multichannel video programming distributor] and on Netflix.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Given the size of your subscriber base, is it getting easier to negotiate content deals or is there still a level of animosity with some content owners that must be worked through?
componenttext: Given the size of your subscriber base, is it getting easier to negotiate content deals or is there still a level of animosity with some content owners that must be worked through?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't think there's any animosity. It's only a question of is our check big enough. And so as we get a larger subscriber base, that becomes easier to write bigger checks. And it's very respectful, I would say, across the board.
componenttext: I don't think there's any animosity. It's only a question of is our check big enough. And so as we get a larger subscriber base, that becomes easier to write bigger checks. And it's very respectful, I would say, across the board.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Moving to the topic of international. In terms of international expansion and content acquisition in non-U.S. markets, what type of expenditures do you anticipate making for locally relevant content, and how might deals with foreign outlets differ from do
componenttext: Moving to the topic of international. In terms of international expansion and content acquisition in non-U.S. markets, what type of expenditures do you anticipate making for locally relevant content, and how might deals with foreign outlets differ from domestic deals?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, were not sure of how much local content will be important for Netflix. With Canada, we've got a fair amount of Canadian content and it's quite successful for us. And our new territories will also license some local content, and then we'll feel ou
componenttext: Well, were not sure of how much local content will be important for Netflix. With Canada, we've got a fair amount of Canadian content and it's quite successful for us. And our new territories will also license some local content, and then we'll feel our way along as we see what's our subscribers are viewing and what they enjoy.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'd say there's an opportunity here outside the U.S. in some markets. And with respect to some local content, there might not be a secondary market or a third or fourth sort of channel for the content owner. So to the extent that we might be the only synd
componenttext: I'd say there's an opportunity here outside the U.S. in some markets. And with respect to some local content, there might not be a secondary market or a third or fourth sort of channel for the content owner. So to the extent that we might be the only syndicated buyer in the market, it's going to work well for us in terms of the economics.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Will new geographies take priority over the U.S. as you build out content? Or should we continue to expect the U.S. to see the bulk of the spending?
componenttext: Will new geographies take priority over the U.S. as you build out content? Or should we continue to expect the U.S. to see the bulk of the spending?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think you should think about them as separate. We'll run the U.S. around 14% operating margin and spend on content in accordance with that. And in international, you'll spend as we see appropriate to launch the service, where weve, obviously, got spe
componenttext: I think you should think about them as separate. We'll run the U.S. around 14% operating margin and spend on content in accordance with that. And in international, you'll spend as we see appropriate to launch the service, where weve, obviously, got spending ahead of revenue. And then as rapidly as possible, within 8 quarters in our target model get each territory to be positive operating margin. In Canada, we've been very successful and we intend to be at breakeven on a operating contribution basis within 4 quarters of launch which is in Q3 and really quite extraordinary. That's probably too high a bar for every international territory, but 8 quarters feels good.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the topic of Canada, can you provide a little color on how the ISP bandwidth cap in Canada have impacted consumer behavior? What percentage of your Canadian customers are using the new "managed video quality tool" in watching lower quality video? Also
componenttext: On the topic of Canada, can you provide a little color on how the ISP bandwidth cap in Canada have impacted consumer behavior? What percentage of your Canadian customers are using the new "managed video quality tool" in watching lower quality video? Also do you believe ISPs in the U.S. or other countries are thinking of capping bandwidth in a similar strict fashion?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We don't have any indication that in the U.S. low, call it, below 100 gigabytes data caps are going to become a significant offering. In Canada, it's switched to default so every virtually everybody is on our low data usage, slightly lower video quality p
componenttext: We don't have any indication that in the U.S. low, call it, below 100 gigabytes data caps are going to become a significant offering. In Canada, it's switched to default so every virtually everybody is on our low data usage, slightly lower video quality plan. And it is helping both directly in terms of the usage and indirectly in terms of the general fear of usage charges, so it's a mitigator. I'm not sure I would call it a solution. It helps. I think, the right solution, over time, is that Canadians enjoy great untapped Internet like the rest of the developed world.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Related question, how do usage patterns in Canada perform relative to your expectation given the various cap rates? What drove the more modest subscriber growth performance relative to your expectations?
componenttext: Related question, how do usage patterns in Canada perform relative to your expectation given the various cap rates? What drove the more modest subscriber growth performance relative to your expectations?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think on what drove the overshoot on the forecast is just we don't have any seasonal data. So the growth was very consistent throughout the quarter, and we're really happy with it. And it's a pretty small percentage, but we just don't have multiple year
componenttext: I think on what drove the overshoot on the forecast is just we don't have any seasonal data. So the growth was very consistent throughout the quarter, and we're really happy with it. And it's a pretty small percentage, but we just don't have multiple years of year-on-year data. In terms of the caps, they play a role, but they played a role from inception. The caps are not something that were new this quarter. The caps have been in effect for a year or more in Canada.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just to add to that, we achieved 8% of broadband household penetration in Canada in 7 months. It took us 6 years in the U.S. to get there. Just so that you don't feel like we're sort of trying to makes ourselves feel better on the forecasting is we're hap
componenttext: Just to add to that, we achieved 8% of broadband household penetration in Canada in 7 months. It took us 6 years in the U.S. to get there. Just so that you don't feel like we're sort of trying to makes ourselves feel better on the forecasting is we're happy about the business. We think weve got a great business going in Canada and we're excited about going forward.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Another related question. The shareholder letter mentioned the seasonality curve in Canada. Can you elaborate on this comment? Is your initial sense that the markets similar to other colder regions, where subscriber growth is more tepid in the warm months
componenttext: Another related question. The shareholder letter mentioned the seasonality curve in Canada. Can you elaborate on this comment? Is your initial sense that the markets similar to other colder regions, where subscriber growth is more tepid in the warm months?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll know in 1.5 year from now after we've gone through the initial seasonality is massed by the launch. And so you really can't get a clean read until at least a year from now about the beginnings of the seasonality effect.
componenttext: We'll know in 1.5 year from now after we've gone through the initial seasonality is massed by the launch. And so you really can't get a clean read until at least a year from now about the beginnings of the seasonality effect.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Is it reasonable to assume that Netflix could enter as many as two international markets or more per year starting in 2012?
componenttext: Is it reasonable to assume that Netflix could enter as many as two international markets or more per year starting in 2012?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: If we continue to see the kind of success that we've seen in Canada, if we think it would be very smart for us to move at least that fast, yes.
componenttext: If we continue to see the kind of success that we've seen in Canada, if we think it would be very smart for us to move at least that fast, yes.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: You noted a high probability of success in our second international market, driving early content commitments for a third market  What are the data points that you focus us on to define success prior to launching in a market?
componenttext: You noted a high probability of success in our second international market, driving early content commitments for a third market  What are the data points that you focus us on to define success prior to launching in a market?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: The reason that we feel a high degree of confidence is how well Canada has done, how well our licensing has gone for content in our second international market, and our qualitative focus group work on the reactions in that market for our service. So those
componenttext: The reason that we feel a high degree of confidence is how well Canada has done, how well our licensing has gone for content in our second international market, and our qualitative focus group work on the reactions in that market for our service. So those are all very healthy indicators that we'll enjoy success.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And those qualitative factors have a lot to do with how much that content is going to cost us relative to where we think we could price it and the consumers' willingness to pay based on their other entertainment alternatives. And we've grown more, I think
componenttext: And those qualitative factors have a lot to do with how much that content is going to cost us relative to where we think we could price it and the consumers' willingness to pay based on their other entertainment alternatives. And we've grown more, I think, confident over the last year given where we think those economics are going to work out.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Moving to the topic of subscribers and subscriber metrics. Do you think we get tiered pricing for multiuser households from Netflix by year end? In that case, how big an addressable market is it?
componenttext: Moving to the topic of subscribers and subscriber metrics. Do you think we get tiered pricing for multiuser households from Netflix by year end? In that case, how big an addressable market is it?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, what weve said before was that the individual subscriber market is that 2 to 3 or few year, I think is how we characterized it in the last Investor Letter. And we haven't changed our point of view. This is a gradual evolution. It's not going to b
componenttext: Well, what weve said before was that the individual subscriber market is that 2 to 3 or few year, I think is how we characterized it in the last Investor Letter. And we haven't changed our point of view. This is a gradual evolution. It's not going to be an immediate 90- or 180-day thing for Netflix. And I think pricing is certainly part of that evolution, changes to the interface are part of that evolution, changes to how we -- if and when we enforce concurrent stream limits, either per device or by account. So there's lots of things for us to figure out and tease out. We wouldn't want to alienate the subscriber or the consumer as we go through those. And I think that we'll evolve to those over the next couple of years.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you share any details on Facebook integration that you are working on? What will be the primary objective of the same? Enhance your recommendation engine or drive engagement or acquire subscribers?
componenttext: Can you share any details on Facebook integration that you are working on? What will be the primary objective of the same? Enhance your recommendation engine or drive engagement or acquire subscribers?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's better for us to share those details when we launch that. So I'll defer that.
componenttext: It's better for us to share those details when we launch that. So I'll defer that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Are you starting to see DVD subscribers trade down from multi-op subscription?
componenttext: Are you starting to see DVD subscribers trade down from multi-op subscription?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. In fact, what we've said before is that basically downward migration and upward migration are canceling each other, and that's what we continue to see. With respect to the price change, we saw behavior that was more linked to the immedia
componenttext: I don't think so. In fact, what we've said before is that basically downward migration and upward migration are canceling each other, and that's what we continue to see. With respect to the price change, we saw behavior that was more linked to the immediate announcement than to the credit card change. Meaning when a subscriber actually got the change to the price on their bill, there wasn't as much activity as when they were notified of the change.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: So related to the price increase. Was the price increase a contributor to the increase in churn or was it more of a normal seasonal pattern?
componenttext: So related to the price increase. Was the price increase a contributor to the increase in churn or was it more of a normal seasonal pattern?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Normal seasonal pattern. It's also a factor of the tremendous growth we saw in Q1. If you followed our company for a long time, you'll note that when we grow quickly, our churn goes up because the retention rates of early subscriber are lower than those s
componenttext: Normal seasonal pattern. It's also a factor of the tremendous growth we saw in Q1. If you followed our company for a long time, you'll note that when we grow quickly, our churn goes up because the retention rates of early subscriber are lower than those subscribers that have been around for 12 or more months. And we continue to see that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Another question on churn. Can you comment some on the churn rates for streaming-only customers in the U.S.? And is it above or below the average? Do you expect a decline over time as customers are maybe testing out this service today?
componenttext: Another question on churn. Can you comment some on the churn rates for streaming-only customers in the U.S.? And is it above or below the average? Do you expect a decline over time as customers are maybe testing out this service today?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: What we said is streaming only has a higher churn rate. It's easier to get in of and out of so it's the same as we said last quarter.
componenttext: What we said is streaming only has a higher churn rate. It's easier to get in of and out of so it's the same as we said last quarter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes and we've said before that the streaming-only plan actually crossed over the DVD only. So that is retention for streaming-only subscribers is actually a higher rate than DVD-only subscribers. It's going to be slightly lower than hybrid, but it's bette
componenttext: Yes and we've said before that the streaming-only plan actually crossed over the DVD only. So that is retention for streaming-only subscribers is actually a higher rate than DVD-only subscribers. It's going to be slightly lower than hybrid, but it's better.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And the final question on churn. It still seems like the overall churn rate for the company is still high relative to other MVPD companies, and causes you to respend SAC [subscriber acquisition cost] dollars on customers that have already been Netflix sub
componenttext: And the final question on churn. It still seems like the overall churn rate for the company is still high relative to other MVPD companies, and causes you to respend SAC [subscriber acquisition cost] dollars on customers that have already been Netflix subscribers in the past? If your customer satisfaction is very high on your streaming products, shouldn't your churn materially decline over the next 18 months in the United States?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, given how stable churn has been the last 2 years, I'd be hard put to think why it should suddenly decline in the next 18 months. And the question refers to us like other MVPD, and  MVPD is a much different service. It's premises-based. It's more exp
componenttext: Well, given how stable churn has been the last 2 years, I'd be hard put to think why it should suddenly decline in the next 18 months. And the question refers to us like other MVPD, and  MVPD is a much different service. It's premises-based. It's more expensive, and it's more considered an essential service so it's really just quite different in all those dimensions. We have a low subscriber acquisition cost, and we have higher churn. And people do test out the service, come back, go out, go in. And that's fine because our overall growth, our net adds are continuing to increase.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Moving to the topic of SAC. Why did the domestic SAC rise so much quarter-over-quarter? Which should be the right base level going forward, Q4's 10 87? Or Q1's 14 38?
componenttext: Moving to the topic of SAC. Why did the domestic SAC rise so much quarter-over-quarter? Which should be the right base level going forward, Q4's 10 87? Or Q1's 14 38?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's no such thing as a right base for going forward, but what weve said in the last quarter's Investor Letter and we reiterate it in this Investor Letter is that we identified the fact that we would have additional money. We would love to spend it
componenttext: There's no such thing as a right base for going forward, but what weve said in the last quarter's Investor Letter and we reiterate it in this Investor Letter is that we identified the fact that we would have additional money. We would love to spend it on streaming content. Because of the complexity of those contracts, there's more lead time acquired and therefore, we put the money into marketing. So the higher SACs sequentially from Q4 to Q1 is a somewhat of an artifact of additional marketing dollars we spent up to the efficient point in Q1. And we'll continue to make that trade-off going forward. Now what we've said in the Investor Letter, just to remind folks, is that we're going to weigh streaming cost. We plan to do that. We're going to continue to do that, and so you should see marketing as a percentage of revenue somewhat mollified relative to Q1.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: As subscribers have grown to streaming, how's the demographics of the Netflix subscriber changed? Is the demographic in Canada comparable to the U.S.?
componenttext: As subscribers have grown to streaming, how's the demographics of the Netflix subscriber changed? Is the demographic in Canada comparable to the U.S.?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, there is no material difference, in fact.
componenttext: Yes, there is no material difference, in fact.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you get U.S. in SF [San Francisco] Bay Area household penetration?
componenttext: Can you get U.S. in SF [San Francisco] Bay Area household penetration?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We've done question this before and what Ill respond by saying that the penetration in the U.S. is 21%. You can calculate that for yourself by looking at the 22.8 million U.S. subscribers and taking it over roughly 110 million households. The reason th
componenttext: We've done question this before and what Ill respond by saying that the penetration in the U.S. is 21%. You can calculate that for yourself by looking at the 22.8 million U.S. subscribers and taking it over roughly 110 million households. The reason that people ask us this is we've given out Bay Area before because when we launched the DVD service back in 1999, we started in the Bay Area. And we had thought at that time that the Bay Area would be a good proxy for the rest of the country. We've come and evolved that notion to believe that that's not necessarily the case especially with a streaming product that we've launched nationally. So in terms of penetration, it's 21% U.S.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your Letter to Shareholders mentioned that you expect DVD shipments to decline slightly year-over-year. In the past, Netflix has announced various milestones in DVD shipments such as 1 billion that were in 2007 and 2 billion April 2009 just shipped. When
componenttext: Your Letter to Shareholders mentioned that you expect DVD shipments to decline slightly year-over-year. In the past, Netflix has announced various milestones in DVD shipments such as 1 billion that were in 2007 and 2 billion April 2009 just shipped. When did Netflix ship the 3 billion discs? Are there other notable DVD milestones?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our focus is really on streaming at this point. So I don't anticipate that we would have or will make those kind of announcements.
componenttext: Our focus is really on streaming at this point. So I don't anticipate that we would have or will make those kind of announcements.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Moving to the topic of competition. Can you speak to the competitive landscape sans peers [ph] and how serious it is today versus, say, a year ago, especially with Amazon's free video streaming offering and with Dish streaming HBO content and Starz channe
componenttext: Moving to the topic of competition. Can you speak to the competitive landscape sans peers [ph] and how serious it is today versus, say, a year ago, especially with Amazon's free video streaming offering and with Dish streaming HBO content and Starz channels for free?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, a big market attracts a lot of competition. I think, it's pretty clear to everyone that online video is a big opportunity. There'll be a number of substantial competitors. If Dish launches something into the Blockbuster brand, that'll be the newest
componenttext: Well, a big market attracts a lot of competition. I think, it's pretty clear to everyone that online video is a big opportunity. There'll be a number of substantial competitors. If Dish launches something into the Blockbuster brand, that'll be the newest entrant. Clearly, Hulu Plus and Amazon may or may not have been having a success but they haven't held us back at all, at what you'd expect to the growing market because in Q1, domestically, our net adds were up over 90%. So we feel great about that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: You mentioned Dish as a competitor. Could you elaborate? Blockbuster is currently a VOD product, white labeling Sonic technology. Do you expect that to change?
componenttext: You mentioned Dish as a competitor. Could you elaborate? Blockbuster is currently a VOD product, white labeling Sonic technology. Do you expect that to change?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We really don't know what Dish is up to, but presumably they paid a couple hundred million for Blockbuster not for its technology but for its brand. It's a well-known brand. And they would do that, it would be consistent to do that if they had plans to la
componenttext: We really don't know what Dish is up to, but presumably they paid a couple hundred million for Blockbuster not for its technology but for its brand. It's a well-known brand. And they would do that, it would be consistent to do that if they had plans to launch a service with a fair amount of content and a fair amount of marketing such that it would make sense to pay $300 million to be able to use the Blockbuster brand.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: One more question on competition. How do you look at HBO and HBO GO as a competitive product as it prepares to expand across the many platforms Netflix currently occupies?
componenttext: One more question on competition. How do you look at HBO and HBO GO as a competitive product as it prepares to expand across the many platforms Netflix currently occupies?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, HBO GO is an implementation of TV Everywhere. A consumer can't subscribe to HBO GO directly. And so it really doesn't compete today. I would say our overall effort that TV Everywhere is making is how to improve MVPD. And one aspect of that is HBO On
componenttext: Well, HBO GO is an implementation of TV Everywhere. A consumer can't subscribe to HBO GO directly. And so it really doesn't compete today. I would say our overall effort that TV Everywhere is making is how to improve MVPD. And one aspect of that is HBO Online. But for example, in the Comcast implementation, you don't use HBO GO as the user interface. You use the Xfinity user interface. And so, I think, you'll see different implementations and the only -- the competitive threat to take out of that for us is TV Everywhere.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Moving on to questions about the financials. In response to a question posed last quarter regarding the significant increase in AP, the company indicated that "largely payments, are at a short timing at the end of the quarter that could reverse itself in
componenttext: Moving on to questions about the financials. In response to a question posed last quarter regarding the significant increase in AP, the company indicated that "largely payments, are at a short timing at the end of the quarter that could reverse itself in Q1." Can the company indicate why did this not reverse in Q1 and instead AP increased further?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: So I was just responding to you the sequential increase in AP last quarter. I answered it somewhat narrowly in saying that the two contrasts that drove that AP increase were going to reverse themselves out in Q2, and they did. On top of that, in addition
componenttext: So I was just responding to you the sequential increase in AP last quarter. I answered it somewhat narrowly in saying that the two contrasts that drove that AP increase were going to reverse themselves out in Q2, and they did. On top of that, in addition to that, we signed a bunch of new content deals that we discussed in the Investor Letter. And to the extent that those deals were within a year with identified titles, it drove the AP up. So let me answer this in a general sense. Cash payments for content increased $130 million year-over-year versus $110 million year-over-year increase in the expense associated with that content. So to the extent that we'd talked about close matching of our payment terms with our expense, we are continuing to execute on that. We ran a little bit ahead in Q1. In terms of the sequential increase, the cash out the door for content was roughly in line with the expense increase. So I think you should see the accounts payable and the associated long-term accrued payable line increase with our continued investment in streaming content. I don't think you'll see it increase at quite the same rate, say, going forward as you saw in the last couple of quarters, but it will go up.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you explain the large sequential and year-over-year drop in acquisitions for the DVD content library?
componenttext: Can you explain the large sequential and year-over-year drop in acquisitions for the DVD content library?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, repeat that one more time.
componenttext: I'm sorry, repeat that one more time.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I can handle it. There's a mix there when you do a rev share title. Most of the expense, essentially all of it, does not go through that line. So that can be a shift towards rev share from purchasing DVDs.
componenttext: I can handle it. There's a mix there when you do a rev share title. Most of the expense, essentially all of it, does not go through that line. So that can be a shift towards rev share from purchasing DVDs.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the streaming side, are storage and incoming costs typically fixed or variable? And are they significant relative to content delivery cost?
componenttext: On the streaming side, are storage and incoming costs typically fixed or variable? And are they significant relative to content delivery cost?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: They are not significant.
componenttext: They are not significant.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, not significant.
componenttext: No, not significant.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: What drove the G&A increase in the quarter, and what are your expectations going forward?
componenttext: What drove the G&A increase in the quarter, and what are your expectations going forward?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: So mostly headcount. There were some increase related to stock comp expense due to employees taking more equity compensation versus cash competition, but mostly a headcount increase.
componenttext: So mostly headcount. There were some increase related to stock comp expense due to employees taking more equity compensation versus cash competition, but mostly a headcount increase.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Why is fulfillment cost still growing? Do you expect it to slow as DVD shipments decline?
componenttext: Why is fulfillment cost still growing? Do you expect it to slow as DVD shipments decline?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Fulfillment cost as a percent of revenue is actually declining. Fulfillment, the absolute fulfillment cost is growing because we shipped more in the quarter. We have more subscribers that have more credit card expense associated with them with their reven
componenttext: Fulfillment cost as a percent of revenue is actually declining. Fulfillment, the absolute fulfillment cost is growing because we shipped more in the quarter. We have more subscribers that have more credit card expense associated with them with their revenue. But as a percent of revenue, it's actually been declining over last 6 quarters or so.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question. If you are a growth company, why are you dividending cash out to shareholders rather than reinvesting it back into the business?
componenttext: Next question. If you are a growth company, why are you dividending cash out to shareholders rather than reinvesting it back into the business?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're generating cash flow when we anticipate continuing to generate cash flow.
componenttext: We're generating cash flow when we anticipate continuing to generate cash flow.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I think we're doing both. I think we're trying to draw a fine distinction between being a pure company that invests everything we possibly have into growth and also returning some to shareholders. So I think it's consistent with the strategy that we'v
componenttext: And I think we're doing both. I think we're trying to draw a fine distinction between being a pure company that invests everything we possibly have into growth and also returning some to shareholders. So I think it's consistent with the strategy that we've had for quite some time of trying to draw both, to do both; be a growth company and also make sure that we're not setting up a false promise to return earnings down the road.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Turning to a handful of miscellaneous questions. When will we start seeing Netflix streaming on Android devices? Will future versions of Androids solve the DRM [digital rights management] issues that prevent making Netflix widely available on the platform
componenttext: Turning to a handful of miscellaneous questions. When will we start seeing Netflix streaming on Android devices? Will future versions of Androids solve the DRM [digital rights management] issues that prevent making Netflix widely available on the platform?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're working hard on Android. Don't have any news at this call. It's a big priority for us, and stay tuned.
componenttext: We're working hard on Android. Don't have any news at this call. It's a big priority for us, and stay tuned.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Device partitions have been a significant component of building out the footprint of streaming subs domestically, and it seems like it could be used as a valuable tool in building out the international footprint. To what extent will your U.S. device partn
componenttext: Device partitions have been a significant component of building out the footprint of streaming subs domestically, and it seems like it could be used as a valuable tool in building out the international footprint. To what extent will your U.S. device partnerships be applicable internationally? Or what will it take build out a similar ecosystem of devices?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We very much expect to work with our CE partners around the world. And certainly in Canada, we've already done that with specific Canadian implementations across all of our major CE partners. And there's now many, many devices in the Canadian market. And
componenttext: We very much expect to work with our CE partners around the world. And certainly in Canada, we've already done that with specific Canadian implementations across all of our major CE partners. And there's now many, many devices in the Canadian market. And that's a good blueprint for what we'll be doing going forward.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: In the press release, you say TV shows and feature films are consumed in equal volumes. Is that true domestically and in Canada?
componenttext: In the press release, you say TV shows and feature films are consumed in equal volumes. Is that true domestically and in Canada?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's approximately true in both, yes.
componenttext: It's approximately true in both, yes.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Moving to a marketing question. [indiscernible] is likely to be a very lucrative upfront process for both broadcast and cable networks come this May and June? Do you see it paying what is rumored to possibly be as high as low teens price hikes for the net
componenttext: Moving to a marketing question. [indiscernible] is likely to be a very lucrative upfront process for both broadcast and cable networks come this May and June? Do you see it paying what is rumored to possibly be as high as low teens price hikes for the network add inventory for marketing purposes? Or do you just bypass network television spending and gear your marketing spend more towards lower CPN alternative such as outdoor or radio?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We always try to market most efficiently we can. And sometimes if one channel, say, outdoor or online or print or network to increasing costs, it would get less of our total dollars. So it's a big broad mix of which the 2 primary components for us are onl
componenttext: We always try to market most efficiently we can. And sometimes if one channel, say, outdoor or online or print or network to increasing costs, it would get less of our total dollars. So it's a big broad mix of which the 2 primary components for us are online and television, not necessarily network but cable offering.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. Okay, so that's the last question for today. Wed like to thank everyone for your time, and we look forward to speaking with you again next quarter.
componenttext: Great. Okay, so that's the last question for today. Wed like to thank everyone for your time, and we look forward to speaking with you again next quarter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, everyone.
componenttext: Thanks, everyone.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Ladies and gentlemen, this does conclude today's program. Thank you for your participation and have a wonderful day. Attendees, you may now disconnect.
componenttext: Thank you. Ladies and gentlemen, this does conclude today's program. Thank you for your participation and have a wonderful day. Attendees, you may now disconnect.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Netflix Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Q&A Session Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Now I would like to pass the call over to Ellie Mertz, Vice President of Finance and Investor Relations.
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Netflix Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Q&A Session Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Now I would like to pass the call over to Ellie Mertz, Vice President of Finance and Investor Relations.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Q&A Session. I'm joined here by Reed Hastings, CEO; and David Wells, CFO. We announced our financial results for the second quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific time
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Q&A Session. I'm joined here by Reed Hastings, CEO; and David Wells, CFO. We announced our financial results for the second quarter at approximately 1:05 p.m. Pacific time today, the shareholder letter and the Q2 financial results and the webcast of this Q&A session are all available at the company's Investor Relations website at ir.netflix.com. As is our standard practice, this call will consist solely of Q&A and we're going to conduct the Q&A via e-mail. Please e-mail your questions to ir@netflix.com. We may make forward-looking statements during this call regarding the company's future performance. Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to risks and uncertainties related to the business. A detailed discussion of such risks and uncertainties is contained in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the commission on February 18, 2011. A rebroadcast of this Q&A session will be available at the Netflix website after 6:00 p.m. Pacific time today. 
Now let's move directly to questions. So as with the last quarter, we have organized the questions by topic as we receive them via e-mail this afternoon. We'll start with questions about the pricing changes we announced just 2 weeks ago.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: How are you feeling about the price increase 2 weeks since announcing it? Do you expect that some of ties subscriber be churning off with the price increase that they will return later once they try other alternatives?
componenttext: How are you feeling about the price increase 2 weeks since announcing it? Do you expect that some of ties subscriber be churning off with the price increase that they will return later once they try other alternatives?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Reed. Like any customer-driven organization, we feel bad about having customers upset with us. But we feel great about the amazing new content we're going to be able to license in the fourth quarter and next year which will further propel our grow
componenttext: This is Reed. Like any customer-driven organization, we feel bad about having customers upset with us. But we feel great about the amazing new content we're going to be able to license in the fourth quarter and next year which will further propel our growth and our subscriber satisfaction. And the price change takes effect upon each subscribers who enroll in September. So we don't have a full range view of it. But so far from what we've seen, we've been very pleased at the effects and we're feeling great about the decision as tough as it is and it's going to allow us to have this fantastic streaming content going forward.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: While still early, could you help us understand the initial effects of the subscription plan pricing change so the net effect on subscriber growth, churn and ARPU?
componenttext: While still early, could you help us understand the initial effects of the subscription plan pricing change so the net effect on subscriber growth, churn and ARPU?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Because of the timing we announced at the very beginning of the quarter, we will see the negative effects of it in Q3. That is the elevated churn and lower revenue growth that we would otherwise have. Then the price increase takes effect essentially mid-S
componenttext: Because of the timing we announced at the very beginning of the quarter, we will see the negative effects of it in Q3. That is the elevated churn and lower revenue growth that we would otherwise have. Then the price increase takes effect essentially mid-September on average. So we get a little bit of benefit at the end of the quarter and then the real benefit comes in the following quarters, Q4 and beyond. But in terms of tracking where we are and our expectations, we're feeling very good.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you tell us what percentage of subscriber have canceled the service? Have you seeing subscribers migrate more towards the plans or towards the DVD plans or they update for both?
componenttext: Can you tell us what percentage of subscriber have canceled the service? Have you seeing subscribers migrate more towards the plans or towards the DVD plans or they update for both?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we're making estimates for the end of the quarter. That's what's in our guidance. And we'll see overtime what the split is. We feel great when you think about it with our DVD service at $7.99. It's an incredible value. It's the lowest priced offer i
componenttext: Well, we're making estimates for the end of the quarter. That's what's in our guidance. And we'll see overtime what the split is. We feel great when you think about it with our DVD service at $7.99. It's an incredible value. It's the lowest priced offer in the market place, it's the best service levels in the marketplace. So it's if the customer wants DVD rental by mail, we're definitely the place to go. And then in terms of streaming, we've gained increasing confidence over the last 2 years about the viability and strength of a pure streaming plan. We gained some confidence when we launched in Canada and that Blu-Ray expectations and the response. We gained some confidence when we led on our nonmember homepage with streaming only. And as we put in our shareholder letter in Q2, about 75% of subscribers chose streaming only. In other words, even though DVD was only $2 more, 75% stuff was streaming only. And again with this pricing change, we're going to be able to strengthen that streaming plan with more content. So that's why we feel good about it.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just to add on to that, our guidance in the letter shows people the strength of the offerings in the sense that we do feel that most people are taking the hybrid offering. A lot of these hybrid subscribers are staying on both plans and that is implied in
componenttext: Just to add on to that, our guidance in the letter shows people the strength of the offerings in the sense that we do feel that most people are taking the hybrid offering. A lot of these hybrid subscribers are staying on both plans and that is implied in both the guidance and the diagram that we put into the letter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I have a question on timing. When did you implement the recent pricing changes now when subscriber growth is near the highest you've ever had? Why not wait until you are further into your penetration curve?
componenttext: I have a question on timing. When did you implement the recent pricing changes now when subscriber growth is near the highest you've ever had? Why not wait until you are further into your penetration curve?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the reason that we felt confident about doing it now is the strength of streaming only, really, we got convinced that we can drive on streaming only. And with the great new content, we're going to be able to get with this pricing change, the
componenttext: Well, I think the reason that we felt confident about doing it now is the strength of streaming only, really, we got convinced that we can drive on streaming only. And with the great new content, we're going to be able to get with this pricing change, the best timing was now.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Why did you decide to push through such a large pricing increase over a smaller, less attractive one?
componenttext: Why did you decide to push through such a large pricing increase over a smaller, less attractive one?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We didn't approach it as what percent price increase in should one do. And I think if we had, we probably wouldn't have gone to 60% so I can understand the question. We really approached it on what we should separate the businesses and the plans because s
componenttext: We didn't approach it as what percent price increase in should one do. And I think if we had, we probably wouldn't have gone to 60% so I can understand the question. We really approached it on what we should separate the businesses and the plans because streaming only was going to become a global offering. And we wanted to really focus on that global streaming offering. And DVD is an incredible U.S.-based plan that's very profitable. It's very large and we wanted it to be able to be successful and have a group that was going to focus on. And the pricing change somewhat was an outcome of that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Why lower the price on DVD only? As subject to streaming, the economics of the remaining DVD business would appear to be working against you. There's a lot less infrastructure for less subs?
componenttext: Why lower the price on DVD only? As subject to streaming, the economics of the remaining DVD business would appear to be working against you. There's a lot less infrastructure for less subs?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we didn't lower the pricing on DVD only. We never had a DVD-only plan. So the perception of lowering might come from the combination plan which was $9.99 and that was the only way to get DVD. And for someone who is very rural and doesn't have broadb
componenttext: Well, we didn't lower the pricing on DVD only. We never had a DVD-only plan. So the perception of lowering might come from the combination plan which was $9.99 and that was the only way to get DVD. And for someone who is very rural and doesn't have broadband, they are essentially paying that extra $2 for streaming not being able to access it. And so we felt great about making a low price aggressively low-priced $7.99 DVD plan. And that was the right plan to carry forward on our DVD side.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Could you explain in more detail the thought process and drivers behind in separating the DVD only business. You started DVD only marketing again and looking to improve the service after several quarters and effectively putting that part of the service ba
componenttext: Could you explain in more detail the thought process and drivers behind in separating the DVD only business. You started DVD only marketing again and looking to improve the service after several quarters and effectively putting that part of the service back in line?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: One of the aspects that we wanted to get  is that the DVD can last long time as a successful service and generate lots of satisfaction and lots of profits. If we did get a platform to succeed on and it is true that we haven't marketed it much in the last
componenttext: One of the aspects that we wanted to get  is that the DVD can last long time as a successful service and generate lots of satisfaction and lots of profits. If we did get a platform to succeed on and it is true that we haven't marketed it much in the last couple of years, but by now, having it as a division within Netflix, we got a way to measure the P&L and we think it will be a smart investment in its growth and sustainability. And whether that is growth is probably a little bit overstated. That would be an aggressive case. But at least that it will shrink slowly as opposed to rapidly with a little bit of investment. And we'll figure that out over the next couple of quarters.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I think we've always talked about the DVD side of our business in a spectrum of emphasis and focus and rather then being pushed to the extremes, what we've said is that we focused on streaming. We proved it out. We have 2 to 3 quarters of tremendous g
componenttext: And I think we've always talked about the DVD side of our business in a spectrum of emphasis and focus and rather then being pushed to the extremes, what we've said is that we focused on streaming. We proved it out. We have 2 to 3 quarters of tremendous growth. And now, it's the right time to go back and look at how easy it is to find the DVD service, how easy is it for subscribers to find what interests them and that's what I think, this is a step in that progression.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Does the separation of streaming and DVD plan set the stage for the opposition of streaming content on a per subscriber basis?
componenttext: Does the separation of streaming and DVD plan set the stage for the opposition of streaming content on a per subscriber basis?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, there's no connection between those issues.
componenttext: No, there's no connection between those issues.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you please give us a little bit more color on your Q3 guidance? I was hoping to hear your thoughts on your subscribers. Are you expecting significant cancellations with the new price plan? Are we close to the peak number of subscribers Netflix reasona
componenttext: Can you please give us a little bit more color on your Q3 guidance? I was hoping to hear your thoughts on your subscribers. Are you expecting significant cancellations with the new price plan? Are we close to the peak number of subscribers Netflix reasonably helps to attain in the U.S.?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we've answered most of that question in the sense that we provided pretty clear guidance in addition to providing some streaming versus DVD subscriber guidance. I don't think there's any implication that we are nearing the peak and that and I thin
componenttext: I think we've answered most of that question in the sense that we provided pretty clear guidance in addition to providing some streaming versus DVD subscriber guidance. I don't think there's any implication that we are nearing the peak and that and I think that we are expecting Q3 to be a quarter where we have subscribers choosing, where they want to land. And in Q4, we expect to return to growth. That's the comments on the letter indicate.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Netflix thrives on customer service. Did the call volume after the price change surprised you at all? Calls were being disconnected instantaneously. And what about the social media reaction? Was the noise also in line or higher than you expected?
componenttext: Netflix thrives on customer service. Did the call volume after the price change surprised you at all? Calls were being disconnected instantaneously. And what about the social media reaction? Was the noise also in line or higher than you expected?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, believe are not the noise level is actually less than we expected given a 60% price increase for some subscribers. So we knew what we were getting into. We tried to be as straightforward as we could and that has worked up very well for us. In terms
componenttext: Well, believe are not the noise level is actually less than we expected given a 60% price increase for some subscribers. So we knew what we were getting into. We tried to be as straightforward as we could and that has worked up very well for us. In terms of the customer support line that was very short amount of time that it exceeded our capacity there. And now, our service levels have returned to our normal great service levels.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: How does separating your DVD and streaming business impact relationships with the studios? Do you expect the content partnerships to be negotiated separately in the future? What kind of impact does that have?
componenttext: How does separating your DVD and streaming business impact relationships with the studios? Do you expect the content partnerships to be negotiated separately in the future? What kind of impact does that have?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: The content acquisition is mostly been separated for a while. That is movie studios mostly have different divisions between DVD and streaming. And then the television studios very much have been different for a while. So we don't see any significant effec
componenttext: The content acquisition is mostly been separated for a while. That is movie studios mostly have different divisions between DVD and streaming. And then the television studios very much have been different for a while. So we don't see any significant effect coming out of the separation of the plans.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let's move to questions about content. Can the company please address what proportion of total streaming content is obtained under revenue sharing agreements along with as to what types of titles are usually obtained under such arrangements and how the ec
componenttext: Let's move to questions about content. Can the company please address what proportion of total streaming content is obtained under revenue sharing agreements along with as to what types of titles are usually obtained under such arrangements and how the economics of revenue sharing compares to the company's other content purchasing agreements?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: For streaming content, we buy like our industry in pay television and network TV buys and cable networks, which is you have to commit upfront and you have to pay a fixed amount for a time period, typically per year, for access to that content on your netw
componenttext: For streaming content, we buy like our industry in pay television and network TV buys and cable networks, which is you have to commit upfront and you have to pay a fixed amount for a time period, typically per year, for access to that content on your network. So that's the industry in which we compete and we buy in that way. So there's not revenue sharing in the DVD style model. And of course, on DVD, we have some revenue sharing that's it and always has been.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sony Picture's Films are still down from the Netflix service. Could you go directly to Sony and Disney for streaming content or is that the Sony agreement exclusive until 2016, 2017?
componenttext: Sony Picture's Films are still down from the Netflix service. Could you go directly to Sony and Disney for streaming content or is that the Sony agreement exclusive until 2016, 2017?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: The Starz agreement in that industry, for example, HBO, also are exclusive. So it's working through Starz, that is our preferred option.
componenttext: The Starz agreement in that industry, for example, HBO, also are exclusive. So it's working through Starz, that is our preferred option.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: In the shareholder letter, you noted that streaming content deals are "being recognized as assets on our balance sheet" as the content become available to streaming customers. How, if at all, does this affect the former $1.6 billion of commitments related
componenttext: In the shareholder letter, you noted that streaming content deals are "being recognized as assets on our balance sheet" as the content become available to streaming customers. How, if at all, does this affect the former $1.6 billion of commitments related to streaming content license agreements that do not meet the content library recognition criteria? Is this how those commitments move on to the balance sheet? And in that case, how are the assets matched on the liability side of the equation?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: So it's a pretty long question. But in general, that is how the staging area for content contracts as they move into what we call in window or available for streaming. When they do that, depending on the payment terms on the matching side, they'll be cash
componenttext: So it's a pretty long question. But in general, that is how the staging area for content contracts as they move into what we call in window or available for streaming. When they do that, depending on the payment terms on the matching side, they'll be cashed out for a quarter of payment. The quarter of expenses associated with that. And into the extent that there is short-term liabilities, it will move into accounts payable. That's one of the reasons that we discussed at in the letter. And if they're longer than a year, it will increase accrued, the other accrued liabilities. At this point, I'll take those questions and sort of refer you to our IR website. There's a pretty detailed treatment of our content accounting and it should walk you through exactly what happens under each scenario.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Could the company please address: one, what is the tool content obligation as reflected in the content contractual obligations note at the 10-Q outsetting as of 6:30, 2011. And what amount of content obligations are due within the next 12 months?
componenttext: Could the company please address: one, what is the tool content obligation as reflected in the content contractual obligations note at the 10-Q outsetting as of 6:30, 2011. And what amount of content obligations are due within the next 12 months?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. This will fall within the next 2 days as we filed the Q. But right now, there's $2.44 billion in that contractual obligations versus $1.84 billion in the last quarter as of 3:30. And roughly 0.25 or about $625 million of those are related to short t
componenttext: Sure. This will fall within the next 2 days as we filed the Q. But right now, there's $2.44 billion in that contractual obligations versus $1.84 billion in the last quarter as of 3:30. And roughly 0.25 or about $625 million of those are related to short term.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Do you find that demand for streaming titles exceed after the streaming debut or does the demand remained constant over the life of the availability?
componenttext: Do you find that demand for streaming titles exceed after the streaming debut or does the demand remained constant over the life of the availability?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's very title specific so we're very excited about launching Mad Men in a few days and being the exclusive subscription provider of that content. And what we expect to see is a versatile activity and then may slow a little bit. And then there'll be anot
componenttext: It's very title specific so we're very excited about launching Mad Men in a few days and being the exclusive subscription provider of that content. And what we expect to see is a versatile activity and then may slow a little bit. And then there'll be another burst as season 5 goes live on television. And consumers want to go back to seasons 1 through 4 to get into the story. So it gets filled by that outside promotion. So there's a lot of patterns in that way. But in general, we've been very pleased with kind of a continuous viewing that we've seen on when we licensed content that it doesn't die right away and in fact has led a great life.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Work and other outlets. Netflix is in discussion for DreamWorks animation for streaming view. Can you comment on those reports? Or generally, on the potential to take away studio output deals from HBO and other premium services, should we see a potential
componenttext: Work and other outlets. Netflix is in discussion for DreamWorks animation for streaming view. Can you comment on those reports? Or generally, on the potential to take away studio output deals from HBO and other premium services, should we see a potential deal with DreamWorks as a potential hedge on the risk of not renewing with Starz and that's losing access to Disney's family movies?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're always in talks with all of the different providers in terms of licensing more content. But we're cannot comment on the events. If we conclude a deal, we would typically announced that and on a go-forward basis.
componenttext: We're always in talks with all of the different providers in terms of licensing more content. But we're cannot comment on the events. If we conclude a deal, we would typically announced that and on a go-forward basis.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We now move on to questions around our International expansion. A lot of us on the sell side that Latin America and rollout with maybe be just 1 or 2 countries at first followed by an additional 1 to 2 countries 6 months later after you've climbed the lea
componenttext: We now move on to questions around our International expansion. A lot of us on the sell side that Latin America and rollout with maybe be just 1 or 2 countries at first followed by an additional 1 to 2 countries 6 months later after you've climbed the learning curve, instead it's 43 countries simultaneously. What's your reaction to the notion that you guys are biting off more than you can chew. Why not focus on the larger countries first? Why spread marketing dollars so widely?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that's driven by internally some balance between moving too fast and too slow. So you could make the argument that we should just focus on Brazil site and learn some lessons there before expanding to the rest of Latin America. Or you can make the
componenttext: I think that's driven by internally some balance between moving too fast and too slow. So you could make the argument that we should just focus on Brazil site and learn some lessons there before expanding to the rest of Latin America. Or you can make the argument now, we should go even faster and we should do Asia and Europe and South America all at the same time. And we ended up in the middle of doing Latin America and all the countries at the same time. Our primary focus is on the larger countries in terms of where we spend on the marketing. But most of the content deals are Latin America wide so it's inefficient to arbitrarily not allow the service to be in certain countries when we essentially paid for the content for those countries anyway. So that's, where we get to. But we're definitely focused on most of our time and effort on major countries.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you offer us a little color on your progress with signing local content? What will be the local versus American content that's available to consumers in these new countries? Have you been able to secure such local language programming at reasonable ra
componenttext: Can you offer us a little color on your progress with signing local content? What will be the local versus American content that's available to consumers in these new countries? Have you been able to secure such local language programming at reasonable rates?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: As we get closer to launch, we'll have more content to announce. Obviously, in Latin America, there's lots of watching sports, which we're not going to be carrying. There's lots of watching of Hollywood films, which we'll have. And there's lots of viewing
componenttext: As we get closer to launch, we'll have more content to announce. Obviously, in Latin America, there's lots of watching sports, which we're not going to be carrying. There's lots of watching of Hollywood films, which we'll have. And there's lots of viewing of telenovelas and we'll have a very nice compliment for telenovelas for launch.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: What level of streaming content is necessary to launch markets in Latin America? Do you believe it to be more or less in Canada either from a dollar or title perspective?
componenttext: What level of streaming content is necessary to launch markets in Latin America? Do you believe it to be more or less in Canada either from a dollar or title perspective?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we're going to launch with much more content than we did proportionally in Canada. And that's because we are more confident of the outcome, which is part of what we've learned from Canada. We started Canada pretty cautiously and then quickly built u
componenttext: Well, we're going to launch with much more content than we did proportionally in Canada. And that's because we are more confident of the outcome, which is part of what we've learned from Canada. We started Canada pretty cautiously and then quickly built up the content and we have more confidence. And so we're starting even stronger in relative terms in Latin America than we did in Canada.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your guidance for International subscribers seem to suggest that you expect lower subscriber growth in Latin America compared to what happened in Canada. Do you expect adoption rates from Latin America similar to what you experienced in Canada?
componenttext: Your guidance for International subscribers seem to suggest that you expect lower subscriber growth in Latin America compared to what happened in Canada. Do you expect adoption rates from Latin America similar to what you experienced in Canada?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, that would be too aggressive. Canada is consistently rich as opposed to pockets of wealth and Canada is broader and has more broadband penetration per capita and it also has more videogame consoles per capita. So on a per capita basis, it will be slow
componenttext: No, that would be too aggressive. Canada is consistently rich as opposed to pockets of wealth and Canada is broader and has more broadband penetration per capita and it also has more videogame consoles per capita. So on a per capita basis, it will be slower than Canada. On a per broadband household, it will still be slower because of the payment methods and because of the videogame consoles. But still, we're a very optimistic about what we can create and what will happen in Latin America.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Really, to add to that is as Reed mentioned that the major reasons, there's a small brand halo effect in Canada that we don't have down in Latin America as you would imagine. So we're building a brand that is largely unknown down to Latin America so that'
componenttext: Really, to add to that is as Reed mentioned that the major reasons, there's a small brand halo effect in Canada that we don't have down in Latin America as you would imagine. So we're building a brand that is largely unknown down to Latin America so that's a little bit of effect there in terms of speed.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: So moving to questions specifically about Canada. What feedback have you gotten from Canadian subscribers about the data plans? Has the subscriber growth number have been materially affected by the data plan?
componenttext: So moving to questions specifically about Canada. What feedback have you gotten from Canadian subscribers about the data plans? Has the subscriber growth number have been materially affected by the data plan?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We don't think that the subscriber growth number is materially affected by the data plans post our shift a few months ago to default people to the lower data plan, which is a very efficient use of data so the primary things that we're learning in Canada i
componenttext: We don't think that the subscriber growth number is materially affected by the data plans post our shift a few months ago to default people to the lower data plan, which is a very efficient use of data so the primary things that we're learning in Canada is that it operates from a seasonality basis. A little bit like Alaska, which is that summertime is great. People are outdoors and watching less content. And wintertime is cold and dark and people watch a lot of content. So in the U.S., we see more seasonality in Maine and in Alaska than we do, for example, in the rest of the country and Canada is operating consistent with that increased seasonality.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: So based on that, how would you expect that Canada to trend year-over-year in say, Q3 and Q4?
componenttext: So based on that, how would you expect that Canada to trend year-over-year in say, Q3 and Q4?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, in Q3, we had a large pent-up launch. And so it will be difficult for us to match that comp. And I wouldn't add anything other than to the guidance that we've already provided in terms of International subs.
componenttext: Well, in Q3, we had a large pent-up launch. And so it will be difficult for us to match that comp. And I wouldn't add anything other than to the guidance that we've already provided in terms of International subs.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Moving to questions about competition. How is Amazon's deal for CBS content change the landscape for acquiring content? How specifically will that exchange of strategy, if at all?
componenttext: Moving to questions about competition. How is Amazon's deal for CBS content change the landscape for acquiring content? How specifically will that exchange of strategy, if at all?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: It hasn't changed. That deal hasn't changed our perspective. Our brand is strong and focused. And that's what we're continuing to invest in and improve and we haven't been able to detect any effect from the Amazon prime bundling.
componenttext: It hasn't changed. That deal hasn't changed our perspective. Our brand is strong and focused. And that's what we're continuing to invest in and improve and we haven't been able to detect any effect from the Amazon prime bundling.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: What most concerns you about competitive streaming services? Have you seen much traction for Amazon service or HBO GO as the premium and compelling alternative experience in Netflix subscribers?
