componenttext: Well, as we addressed the matter, we think the future is brightest by focusing on streaming. We could, in principle, offer of discounts for hybrid, but if we were going to use discounting dollars, we wouldn't want to trying to incent more DVD use and subsidizing DVDs with want to be discounting streaming and focus on getting even more market share. As it turns out, we think that 799 streaming is such a great price, but mostly, we should focus on continuing to fill out the content. And so we're really quite comfortable with our growth with the 2 799 programs.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Duty to read spending to win that sentiment to drive the virtuous cycle, even if it means lower margins for the next 12 to 18 months, as your programming to spend targets for 2012 change due to the changes in subscriber terms? If so, what type of content
componenttext: Duty to read spending to win that sentiment to drive the virtuous cycle, even if it means lower margins for the next 12 to 18 months, as your programming to spend targets for 2012 change due to the changes in subscriber terms? If so, what type of content are you giving up?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as we said in the letter, the focus for us is in getting back our reputation and brand strength. But that's not through grand gestures, signing some crazy content deal and doing something else. It's the same set of steps that we've been using year a
componenttext: Well, as we said in the letter, the focus for us is in getting back our reputation and brand strength. But that's not through grand gestures, signing some crazy content deal and doing something else. It's the same set of steps that we've been using year after year for the past 10 years in terms of building our brand, which has a steady focus on execution, improving our service quarter-after-quarter. And in terms of our programming content, we do have built into our plans substantial increases in the content investment over this year and over the prior year. It's really exciting that we're able to fit net loss content as we documented in the effect of our letter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you please provide apples-to-apples comparisons for your subscriber guidance? What does it imply on a unique subscriber basis? And how many hybrid subscribers are you assuming this for Q4?
componenttext: Can you please provide apples-to-apples comparisons for your subscriber guidance? What does it imply on a unique subscriber basis? And how many hybrid subscribers are you assuming this for Q4?

componenttext: This is David Wells, the CFO. So in terms of our subscriber guidance what we said in the letter is we will be up slightly from the 23.8 million unique subscribers we need in Q3. So that tells you sort of where we are from a unique subscriber basis. I will say that from a hybrid subscriber basis, we expect streaming only subscribers to grow substantially, DVD only subscribers to be up somewhat, and for those subscribers taking both services to be down. And I think all the pieces are there in the letter and the guidance.

componenttext: Really, we focus on net adds and growing the business. And we make it very easy for customers to exit or cancel Netflix and then come back. So we really don't focus on churn. We focus on total growth with the business or net additions.

componenttext: I think in the long-run, the long-term margin structure for streaming will be ultimately determined by the competitive space and how many competitors we have. In the short run, we've been aggressively adding streaming content at the same rate of subscriber growth and we continue to anticipate investing in that in 2012. But we do have the confidence that we'll be able to grow in pace along with that rate of investment addition. So we think we'll be able to take up contribution margin at the same time.

componenttextpreview: So moving on to questions specifically about the DVD business. I understand the ripping of the Band-Aid off approach, excuse me. I understand the ripping the Band-Aid approach, which used for pricing changes. But what possible rationale could one use to j
componenttext: So moving on to questions specifically about the DVD business. I understand the ripping of the Band-Aid off approach, excuse me. I understand the ripping the Band-Aid approach, which used for pricing changes. But what possible rationale could one use to justify the idea of thing to resolve and build an entirely separate brand like Flixster?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, in hindsight, it's hard to justify. I would tell you that the brand properties of DVD and streaming are quite different. DVD is complete, but it's got the by mail aspect, which is quite slow. And streaming is instant and the selection is less. And s
componenttext: Well, in hindsight, it's hard to justify. I would tell you that the brand properties of DVD and streaming are quite different. DVD is complete, but it's got the by mail aspect, which is quite slow. And streaming is instant and the selection is less. And so having separate brands representing really the different audiences that care about those 2 services can, in theory, make sense. However, in practice, post the price increase, Flixter became the symbol of Netflix not listening. And we quickly changed course on that, and we're going to stick with DVD as part of the Netflix brand. And going forward, we'll be very aggressive on promoting streaming Netflix and the benefits, and anyone who wants to also subscribe to DVD will be very welcome, but we're going to be pushing and promoting streaming.

componenttext: Final question on the DVD business. But the core of our strategy is to create a great customer experience with the content we have using the personalization, the on-demand incredible streaming that we have, and that's what's really propelled our growth over the last several years.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll see. Relative to pay television, it's not a 0 some gain. So many people, including me, subscribe to HBO because it's got incredible content in addition to Netflix. So think of it as a multiple channel. Some people will consume for multiple providers
componenttext: We'll see. Relative to pay television, it's not a 0 some gain. So many people, including me, subscribe to HBO because it's got incredible content in addition to Netflix. So think of it as a multiple channel. Some people will consume for multiple providers. That being said, when budgets are tight, there's a hierarchy of which ones do you use most. And we definitely want to win those. And so our competitive differentiation there is that we're a pure on-demand experience we can create a much better user experience by being pure on-demand, we're highly personalized so it's much easier to discover lots of content we might notice that is unique for each individual. And then, of course, how more enormously great value at $7.99 unlimited and unbundled from the traditional cable system, it creates an incredible value. So those are the primary 3. And then in terms of the many new competitors that's exactly what happens when a big new opportunity. I think everybody sees that Internet video is going to be an enormous market over the next couple of years, and it's completely predictable that there will be many new entrants. And so we're focused on how do we extend our lead and our benefits, again, focused on streaming.

componenttext: Well, we're going to put a pause on our international expansion post the U.K. and Ireland to get back to global profitability. So that depends on how fast we can grow our global subscriber base, which will be some number of quarters. And we're eager to get back to continuing the international expansion because we see it as such a large opportunity. But we need to take a few quarters to get our subscriber base back to the appropriate size.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Sky Movies does have the fixed major studios but there is a wide range of other movie content available from the non-fixed majors, and then there's a tremendous amount of television that's available also. And Sky Movies is expensive at GBP 16, or ab
componenttext: Well, Sky Movies does have the fixed major studios but there is a wide range of other movie content available from the non-fixed majors, and then there's a tremendous amount of television that's available also. And Sky Movies is expensive at GBP 16, or about $25 a month, and it's only taken now by less than 5 million citizens or households. So there's a big opportunity for those who don't have Sky Movies. And then for those who do have Sky Movies for using iTV content selection to attract those subscribers. So the answer to the question about why the U.K. and Ireland because we see a very attractive market with great over-the-top penetration. Many consumers are very comfortable with online video and use it from the on-demand, from BBCi player, Sky Go, all the different providers. So it's a very fertile market in that way. And our big advantage is really knowing streaming technology well, streaming marketing, and we feel great about entering with all of our C. partners.

componenttext: It going on to a question about CE devices. In January of the CES conference you announced that Best Buy, marks, Panasonic, Samsung, Sharp and others would add metric buttons to their remote controls to their devices. Can you give us an update on these partnership? With the device should be in time for the 2011 winter holiday season?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: That the most specifically on specific brands. But on as a whole, I would say the Netflix button program has been going great and there will be lots of devices in the market in Q4 in preparation for Christmas.
componenttext: That the most specifically on specific brands. But on as a whole, I would say the Netflix button program has been going great and there will be lots of devices in the market in Q4 in preparation for Christmas.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: So other miscellaneous questions. What is the company's guidance for future tax rate? I can take this one. We guide to roughly 30% effective tax rate for the full year and probably slightly higher, something around 38% for Q4, lightly trending to say 39%
componenttext: So other miscellaneous questions. What is the company's guidance for future tax rate? I can take this one. We guide to roughly 30% effective tax rate for the full year and probably slightly higher, something around 38% for Q4, lightly trending to say 39% in the following year. If you look at the Q3 effective tax rate, it was quite low at approximately 33%, and that was due to the expiration of some statutory limitations on some past audits. So we have to treat that in Q3 that we won't have in future quarters.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just a clarification we said 37% for the full year, correct?
componenttext: And just a clarification we said 37% for the full year, correct?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. How long will you wait for regulatory in the U.S. related to the issue?
componenttext: Yes. How long will you wait for regulatory in the U.S. related to the issue?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a Bill in Congress now 2471, which clarifies that a consumer does have the right to get permission for their video data that we shared and that predicting what the U.S. Congress is going to is not something we're engaged in. As it passes, th
componenttext: Well, there's a Bill in Congress now 2471, which clarifies that a consumer does have the right to get permission for their video data that we shared and that predicting what the U.S. Congress is going to is not something we're engaged in. As it passes, that's great and fantastic for consumers everywhere. If it doesn't, we'll figure out our next step with that point.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. So at this time, I'd like to turn it over to the operator and begin taking live, call-in questions.
componenttext: Great. So at this time, I'd like to turn it over to the operator and begin taking live, call-in questions.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Youssef Squali from Jefferies and Company.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Youssef Squali from Jefferies and Company.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Reed, just a couple of question or one question going back to the DVD business. Clearly, it's as it starts atrophying, I'm just trying to understand what is the value of that business to you now outside of just being a cash cow? Are there any synergies th
componenttext: Reed, just a couple of question or one question going back to the DVD business. Clearly, it's as it starts atrophying, I'm just trying to understand what is the value of that business to you now outside of just being a cash cow? Are there any synergies that still exist between that and the streaming business? And if there is any value to actually keep it under the Roe?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Youssef, at this point it's a sorts of source of profits funding our international expansion and it's a source of satisfaction to the more than 10 million members who subscribe to our DVD service, whether they also subscribe to streaming or not. And so we
componenttext: Youssef, at this point it's a sorts of source of profits funding our international expansion and it's a source of satisfaction to the more than 10 million members who subscribe to our DVD service, whether they also subscribe to streaming or not. And so we'll keep it and run it steadily and keep the servers almost great for it. So that would be the plan going forward.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from... [Operator Instructions] .
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from... [Operator Instructions] .

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's okay, you guys pick our job as we see it is try to anticipate your questions and answer as many of them proactively in our investor letter as possible. I'll take the absence of telephone questions that, at least in that dimension, we're doing a goo
componenttext: That's okay, you guys pick our job as we see it is try to anticipate your questions and answer as many of them proactively in our investor letter as possible. I'll take the absence of telephone questions that, at least in that dimension, we're doing a good job. And I want to thank everyone for their support. I know it's been an extremely challenging time to be a shareholder over the last couple of months. And I want to tell everyone that we are extremely focused on growing our streaming business on a global basis and believe it's a tremendous opportunity to create a very valuable and important and respected firm, and that's what everyday here at Netflix has been doing. So with that, thank you all very much.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thanks for participating in today's program. This concludes the programming. You may all disconnect.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thanks for participating in today's program. This concludes the programming. You may all disconnect.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Netflix Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Q&A session. Today's call is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Ms. Ellie Mertz, VP of Finance and Investor
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Netflix Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Q&A session. Today's call is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Ms. Ellie Mertz, VP of Finance and Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Q&A session. I am joined here by Reed Hastings, CEO; and David Wells, CFO. We announced our financial results for the third quarter at approximately 5 p.m, Pacific time today
componenttext:
Thank you and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Q&A session. I am joined here by Reed Hastings, CEO; and David Wells, CFO. We announced our financial results for the third quarter at approximately 5 p.m, Pacific time today. The shareholder letter and the Q3 financial results and the webcast of this Q&A session are all available at the company's Investor Relations website at ir.netflix.com. As is our standard practice, we will begin the call with questions received via e-mail. Please e-mail your questions to ir@netflix.com . In the time remaining after e-mail Q&A, we will also open up the lines to take live, follow-up questions. The dial-in number is within our investor letter, but let me repeat it now. Please call (760) 666-3613 if you would like to get in the call queue. 
We may make forward-looking statements during this call regarding the company's future performance. Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to risks and uncertainties related to the business. A detailed discussion of such risks and uncertainties is contained in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the commission on February 18, 2011. A rebroadcast of this Q&A session will be available at the Netflix website after 6 p.m. Pacific time today. 
Now let's move directly to questions. Similar to previous quarters, we have organized the questions by topic as we received them via e-mail this afternoon. We'll start with questions about the domestic business.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Given the sub losses in October, why are you so confident that November will be flat and December will have positive net adds for streaming? What does the churn look like week-to-week in October?
componenttext: Given the sub losses in October, why are you so confident that November will be flat and December will have positive net adds for streaming? What does the churn look like week-to-week in October?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Now, what we've seen is a second wave of cancellations from the price increase. The first wave was in July upon announcement, and the second wave has been in September and October, as people become more aware of the price increase, and many have changed t
componenttext: Now, what we've seen is a second wave of cancellations from the price increase. The first wave was in July upon announcement, and the second wave has been in September and October, as people become more aware of the price increase, and many have changed the plan or canceled. And that wave has been declining very steadily over the past couple of weeks. And so we have substantially less weekly cancels now than we did just 3 to 4 weeks ago. So that's that gives us confidence that it's -- this wave passing through.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Why do you specifically believe your December month domestic net adds will be strongly positive? Do you plan a major marketing campaign to help make this happen?
componenttext: Why do you specifically believe your December month domestic net adds will be strongly positive? Do you plan a major marketing campaign to help make this happen?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: And our marketing has been very successful for the last several years, and we don't plan on any substantial change to it. It's a great set of campaigns that work very well at attracting streaming subscribers. And in Q4, particularly in December, there's m
componenttext: And our marketing has been very successful for the last several years, and we don't plan on any substantial change to it. It's a great set of campaigns that work very well at attracting streaming subscribers. And in Q4, particularly in December, there's more focus on a set of devices, videogaming consoles that get sold, iPads that get sold, a wide range of devices. And so our expectations are modeled from prior year's performance.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Why not reintroduce a combined streaming DVD plan offering at a discount for taking both?
componenttext: Why not reintroduce a combined streaming DVD plan offering at a discount for taking both?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as we addressed in the letter, we think the future is brightest by focusing on streaming. We could, in principle, offer discounts for hybrid, but if we were going to use discounting dollars, we wouldn't want to trying to incent more DVD use and subs
componenttext: Well, as we addressed in the letter, we think the future is brightest by focusing on streaming. We could, in principle, offer discounts for hybrid, but if we were going to use discounting dollars, we wouldn't want to trying to incent more DVD use and subsidizing DVDs, we'd want to be discounting streaming, and focus on getting even more market share. As it turns out, we think that $7.99 streaming is such a great price, but mostly, we should focus on continuing to fill out the content. And so we're really quite comfortable in our growth with the 2 $7.99 programs.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Do you mean to ramp spending to win back sentiment, to drive a virtuous cycle, even if it means lower margins for the next 12 to 18 months, has your programming spend targets for 2012 changed due to the change in subscriber terms? If so, what type of cont
componenttext: Do you mean to ramp spending to win back sentiment, to drive a virtuous cycle, even if it means lower margins for the next 12 to 18 months, has your programming spend targets for 2012 changed due to the change in subscriber terms? If so, what type of content are you giving up?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as we said in the letter, the focus for us is in getting back our reputation and brand strength. But that's not through grand gestures, signing some crazy content deal or doing something else. It's the same set of steps that we've been using year af
componenttext: Well, as we said in the letter, the focus for us is in getting back our reputation and brand strength. But that's not through grand gestures, signing some crazy content deal or doing something else. It's the same set of steps that we've been using year after year for the past 10 years in terms of building our brand, which has a steady focus on execution, improving our service quarter-after-quarter. And in terms of our programming content, we do have built into our plan substantial increases in the content investment over this year and over the prior year. It's really exciting that we're able to fill out that content as we documented in its effect in our letter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you please provide apples-to-apples comparisons for your subscriber guidance? What does it imply on a unique subscriber basis? And how many hybrid subscribers are you assuming for Q4?
componenttext: Can you please provide apples-to-apples comparisons for your subscriber guidance? What does it imply on a unique subscriber basis? And how many hybrid subscribers are you assuming for Q4?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is David Wells, the CFO. So in terms of our subscriber guidance, what we said in the letter is we will be up slightly from the 23.8 million unique subscribers we needed Q3 with. So that tells you sort of where we are from a unique subscriber basis. I
componenttext: This is David Wells, the CFO. So in terms of our subscriber guidance, what we said in the letter is we will be up slightly from the 23.8 million unique subscribers we needed Q3 with. So that tells you sort of where we are from a unique subscriber basis. I will say that from a hybrid subscriber basis, we expect streaming only subscribers to grow substantially, DVD only subscribers to be up somewhat, and for those subscribers taking both services to be down. And I think all the pieces are there in the letter and the guidance.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Would churn peak in Q4?
componenttext: Would churn peak in Q4?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Really, we focus on net adds and growing the business. And we make it very easy for customers to exit or cancel Netflix and then come back. So we really don't focus on churn. We focus on total growth with the business or net additions.
componenttext: Really, we focus on net adds and growing the business. And we make it very easy for customers to exit or cancel Netflix and then come back. So we really don't focus on churn. We focus on total growth with the business or net additions.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I think if they were meaning to ask the question of will the number of people leaving the service related to the price changes, peak in Q4. We've already answered that question in terms of the weekly trends that we see, and the retention rates.
componenttext: And I think if they were meaning to ask the question of will the number of people leaving the service related to the price changes, peak in Q4. We've already answered that question in terms of the weekly trends that we see, and the retention rates.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you provide more detail about around your domestic streaming contribution margins? 8% seems unusually low, given that you already have 21 million streaming subscribers, and should therefore have significant scale. Is there a subscriber level at which
componenttext: Can you provide more detail about around your domestic streaming contribution margins? 8% seems unusually low, given that you already have 21 million streaming subscribers, and should therefore have significant scale. Is there a subscriber level at which you believe your streaming contribution margin will meet or exceed your DVD contribution margin?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think in the long-run, the long-term margin structure for streaming will be ultimately determined by the competitive space, and how many competitors we have. In the short run, we've been aggressively adding streaming content at the same rate of subscrib
componenttext: I think in the long-run, the long-term margin structure for streaming will be ultimately determined by the competitive space, and how many competitors we have. In the short run, we've been aggressively adding streaming content at the same rate of subscriber growth, and we continue to anticipate investing in that in 2012. But we do have the confidence that we'll be able to grow in pace along with that rate of investment addition. So we think we'll be able to take up contribution margin at the same time.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Related question. How will U.S. content cost double in 2012, and contribution margins be up 100 basis points over the quarter?
componenttext: Related question. How will U.S. content cost double in 2012, and contribution margins be up 100 basis points over the quarter?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think I just answered that question, but we would anticipate that the growth of streaming subscribers to outpace the content addition.
componenttext: I think I just answered that question, but we would anticipate that the growth of streaming subscribers to outpace the content addition.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, in the other part is in Q4 of this year, we've taken the content cost way up. So it's not doubling the Q4 levels going forward, it's on a year-over-year basis.
componenttext: Well, in the other part is in Q4 of this year, we've taken the content cost way up. So it's not doubling the Q4 levels going forward, it's on a year-over-year basis.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: What is the impact of the overall vast simplicity [ph] on your cost per addition in each of the streaming and DVD-by-mail categories? Is the adverse impact more so on the streaming side, or the DVD-by-mail segment? I can take this one. As you saw in our i
componenttext: What is the impact of the overall vast simplicity [ph] on your cost per addition in each of the streaming and DVD-by-mail categories? Is the adverse impact more so on the streaming side, or the DVD-by-mail segment? I can take this one. As you saw in our investor letter, Q3 SAC of about $15.25 was actually comparable to the prior quarter. In Q2 we reported a very similar SAC of $15.09, and it was actually down this quarter about $0.24, 24% from a year ago. So to date, we haven't seen any of the negative publicity affect our subscriber acquisition cost.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think what we would imply is that our SAC might be even lower it had we not had a brand hit.
componenttext: I think what we would imply is that our SAC might be even lower it had we not had a brand hit.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: So moving on to questions specifically about the DVD business. I understand the ripping of the Band-Aid off approach, excuse me. I understand the ripping the Band-Aid off approach you used with your pricing changes. But what possible rationale could one u
componenttext: So moving on to questions specifically about the DVD business. I understand the ripping of the Band-Aid off approach, excuse me. I understand the ripping the Band-Aid off approach you used with your pricing changes. But what possible rationale could one use to justify the idea of change and develop and build an entirely separate brand like Flixster?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, in hindsight, it's hard to justify. I would tell you that the brand properties of DVD and streaming are quite different. DVD is complete, but it's got the by mail aspect, which is quite slow. And streaming is instant and the selection is less. And s
componenttext: Well, in hindsight, it's hard to justify. I would tell you that the brand properties of DVD and streaming are quite different. DVD is complete, but it's got the by mail aspect, which is quite slow. And streaming is instant and the selection is less. And so having separate brands representing really the different audiences that care about those 2 services can, in theory, make sense. However, in practice, post the price increase, Flixster became the symbol of Netflix not listening. And we quickly changed course on that, and we're going to stick with DVD as part of the Netflix brand. And going forward, we'll be very aggressive on promoting streaming Netflix and the benefits, and anyone who wants to also subscribe to DVD will be very welcome, but we're going to be pushing and promoting streaming.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: What are your assumptions for growth for the domestic DVD business? Are the DVD trends company specific? Or is there a larger industry trend or change in consumer behavior? I noticed that DVD margins are currently much higher than streaming. What are your
componenttext: What are your assumptions for growth for the domestic DVD business? Are the DVD trends company specific? Or is there a larger industry trend or change in consumer behavior? I noticed that DVD margins are currently much higher than streaming. What are your long-term contribution margin targets for U.S. streaming, international streaming and DVD?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think David answered part of that on the long-term margin. And DVD is partially high margin because of the U.S. per sale block end [ph], where we can buy the DVD, pay for it once, and then rent it as long as we want. So it's an unusually -- it's an unus
componenttext: I think David answered part of that on the long-term margin. And DVD is partially high margin because of the U.S. per sale block end [ph], where we can buy the DVD, pay for it once, and then rent it as long as we want. So it's an unusually -- it's an unusual situation limited to DVD. And then in terms of DVD subscriber counts and base, this quarter, there's a big downdraft, as evidenced in our guidance and then it will be a slow decline over the next what, many years, for DVD. And as we've said in the letter, we don't anticipate further investments and equipment and property brand equipment for DVD. So we think that we can manage that downward.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: And this is a similar, related question. Given that DVD-by-mail is immature, someone called it buddy work [ph], business category for renting recent films, do you anticipate a steady decline in that business, or do you believe there is a stabilized level
componenttext: And this is a similar, related question. Given that DVD-by-mail is immature, someone called it buddy work [ph], business category for renting recent films, do you anticipate a steady decline in that business, or do you believe there is a stabilized level of subscribers that the business is likely to support? In other words, what is the minimum subscriber level required to sustain a reasonably profitable cash cow business in that segment? And how viable do you believe it is?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: It will probably be something like AOL dial-up from 2002 through to today, where it a steady decline ever year a little bit, but there's a long-term residual market. And there's very little fixed cost in the business. So that's not a material cutoff of it
componenttext: It will probably be something like AOL dial-up from 2002 through to today, where it a steady decline ever year a little bit, but there's a long-term residual market. And there's very little fixed cost in the business. So that's not a material cutoff of its efficiency, it's almost all variable cost. The postage, the labor, all of those aspects.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Final question on the DVD business. Historically, Netflix DVD business was so successful because it could effectively monetize the back catalogue, but our rental mix of only 30% new release and 70% back catalogs compared to Blockbuster at effectively 90%
componenttext: Final question on the DVD business. Historically, Netflix DVD business was so successful because it could effectively monetize the back catalogue, but our rental mix of only 30% new release and 70% back catalogs compared to Blockbuster at effectively 90% new release and 10% back catalogue. How has the streaming service affected this mix for hybrid customers? And how much impact on profitability is there as DVD rentals shift towards new releases?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's been no substantial shift in the DVD mix over the last couple of years. And so DVD is still primarily a catalogue rental business, where people like the incredible depth and breath of the catalog, over a 100,000 titles.
componenttext: There's been no substantial shift in the DVD mix over the last couple of years. And so DVD is still primarily a catalogue rental business, where people like the incredible depth and breath of the catalog, over a 100,000 titles.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I would also add to that, that we've said before that Netflix is not the only service that our subscribers use to source of their entertainment. And so to the extent that subscribers also use their local video store, Redbox and other services, they co
componenttext: And I would also add to that, that we've said before that Netflix is not the only service that our subscribers use to source of their entertainment. And so to the extent that subscribers also use their local video store, Redbox and other services, they continue to do that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let's move to questions about content. Have expensive content become more important? What is your bias in terms of paying either higher fees for pure exclusivity, or paying lower rights fees and letting something like Epix become non-exclusive?
componenttext: Let's move to questions about content. Have expensive content become more important? What is your bias in terms of paying either higher fees for pure exclusivity, or paying lower rights fees and letting something like Epix become non-exclusive?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as we mentioned back at, I think, at our April investor letter, the industry is mostly an exclusive licensing industry, and we'll end up doing more and more exclusive over time, and that has been witnessed in what we've seen today. So we do expect t
componenttext: Well, as we mentioned back at, I think, at our April investor letter, the industry is mostly an exclusive licensing industry, and we'll end up doing more and more exclusive over time, and that has been witnessed in what we've seen today. So we do expect to continue to expand exclusive licensing arrangements. And then on Epix specifically, I don't have a comment.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Is original content the key to reenergizing gross additions?
componenttext: Is original content the key to reenergizing gross additions?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: The gross additions are up over a year ago. And, of course, we always want them to be up even more. And original content may play a part in that over time. We've got some smaller, innovative original content with Lillehammer, and some larger high-profile
componenttext: The gross additions are up over a year ago. And, of course, we always want them to be up even more. And original content may play a part in that over time. We've got some smaller, innovative original content with Lillehammer, and some larger high-profile content next fall. And those are nice augmentations to the strategy. But the core of our strategy is to create a great customer experience with the content we have, using the personalization, the on-demand incredible streaming that we have, and that's what's really propelled our growth over the last several years.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Specific question about Epix. The books at Epix say that there is a window setting August 10, allowing Epix the option of either renegotiating new terms on your current deal or leaving the terms as is. Therefore, can you can confirm that this is indeed th
componenttext: Specific question about Epix. The books at Epix say that there is a window setting August 10, allowing Epix the option of either renegotiating new terms on your current deal or leaving the terms as is. Therefore, can you can confirm that this is indeed the case?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: We don't talk about specifics on the deal that we had. I will say that, that date sounds early.
componenttext: We don't talk about specifics on the deal that we had. I will say that, that date sounds early.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: To what extent are your streaming content deals, which usually encompass multiple years on variable cost terms, i.e. tied to subscriber numbers, to better assure maintenance of your operating margin targets? So I can take this one. So essentially, all of
componenttext: To what extent are your streaming content deals, which usually encompass multiple years on variable cost terms, i.e. tied to subscriber numbers, to better assure maintenance of your operating margin targets? So I can take this one. So essentially, all of our streaming content licenses are in a fixed fee basis, and we amortize them straight line over the length of the license agreement. Next question. Do  your content deals include broad changes in control limitations, which would cancel the agreements, if you were ever acquired?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Again, we don't usually talk about specifics but no, there isn't a limitation.
componenttext: Again, we don't usually talk about specifics but no, there isn't a limitation.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Are you okay with being rerun television?
componenttext: Are you okay with being rerun television?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: While I think as I said over last couple of months, it's not how I would characterize it, but it's not fundamentally inaccurate to say that we have incredible complete prior seasons, like the last couple of seasons for "Mad Men" and "Breaking Bad" et cete
componenttext: While I think as I said over last couple of months, it's not how I would characterize it, but it's not fundamentally inaccurate to say that we have incredible complete prior seasons, like the last couple of seasons for "Mad Men" and "Breaking Bad" et cetera, and then that creates a great customer experience, especially for episodic content. And going back on series, you might not have seen all the episodes that you can get into. And so complete prior season, plus a huge selection of movies, is a great combination service.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: The advance of the release of the full 10-Q. Give an updated figure for total off-balance-sheet streaming content commitments.
componenttext: The advance of the release of the full 10-Q. Give an updated figure for total off-balance-sheet streaming content commitments.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. Streaming content commitments in the table will read a $3.5 billion, up from $2.3 billion and that number is inclusive of what's already in the library so essentially, we're writing up another $1.1 billion in the future commitments that don't meet t
componenttext: Sure. Streaming content commitments in the table will read a $3.5 billion, up from $2.3 billion and that number is inclusive of what's already in the library so essentially, we're writing up another $1.1 billion in the future commitments that don't meet the criteria for library recognition.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: What's the split between movie streaming and TV streaming in the U.S. market? Does that differ in Canada?
componenttext: What's the split between movie streaming and TV streaming in the U.S. market? Does that differ in Canada?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: TV, as a percentage of hours, is ahead of movies at this point, and most places in the world for us. But it can vary sometimes on the programming mix. But no round numbers, think about -- it's each about half.
componenttext: TV, as a percentage of hours, is ahead of movies at this point, and most places in the world for us. But it can vary sometimes on the programming mix. But no round numbers, think about -- it's each about half.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: When you say you'll be spending nearly double what you've spent for the content this year in 2012, would that be all new cash outlay, or would that include the multiyear contracts fields you've already in entered into, and currently hold either on or off
componenttext: When you say you'll be spending nearly double what you've spent for the content this year in 2012, would that be all new cash outlay, or would that include the multiyear contracts fields you've already in entered into, and currently hold either on or off the balance sheet?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: It will include the deals that we've already announced and included in some new deals with the mixture of both. But it does include the new deals, I mean, the existing deals.
componenttext: It will include the deals that we've already announced and included in some new deals with the mixture of both. But it does include the new deals, I mean, the existing deals.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: And the increase referred to there is P&L view.
componenttext: And the increase referred to there is P&L view.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure.
componenttext: Sure.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Turning to some questions about competition. What is your competitive advantage competing against the traditional pay channels? What about against all the prevailing new entrants that everyone seems to be so stoked about which is Amazon, Hulu, Dish, Googl
componenttext: Turning to some questions about competition. What is your competitive advantage competing against the traditional pay channels? What about against all the prevailing new entrants that everyone seems to be so stoked about which is Amazon, Hulu, Dish, Google and Apple?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll see. Relative to pay television, it's not a 0 some gain. So many people, including me, subscribe to HBO because it's got incredible content in addition to Netflix. So think of it as multiple channels, and people will consume in -- from multiple prov
componenttext: We'll see. Relative to pay television, it's not a 0 some gain. So many people, including me, subscribe to HBO because it's got incredible content in addition to Netflix. So think of it as multiple channels, and people will consume in -- from multiple providers. That being said, when budgets are tight, there's a hierarchy of which ones do you use most. And we definitely want to win those. And so our competitive differentiation there is that we're a pure on-demand experience, to which we can create a much better user experience by being pure on-demand, we're highly personalized, so it's much easier to discover lots of content we might not know exist that's unique for each individual. And then, of course, how more enormously great value at $7.99 unlimited and unbundled from the traditional cable system, it creates an incredible value. So those are the primary 3. And then in terms of the many new competitors, that's exactly what happens when a big new opportunity. I think everybody sees that Internet video is going to be an enormous market over the next couple of years, and it's completely predictable that there will be many new entrants. And so we're focused on how do we extend our lead and our benefits, again, focused on streaming.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: What, if any impacts, have you seen from Dish Network's effort to build out its Blockbuster Movie Pass streaming option? Same question for Amazon Prime free video offering.
componenttext: What, if any impacts, have you seen from Dish Network's effort to build out its Blockbuster Movie Pass streaming option? Same question for Amazon Prime free video offering.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: From neither one have we seen any impact.
componenttext: From neither one have we seen any impact.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Moving to questions about international. How long will the international expansion be halted?
componenttext: Moving to questions about international. How long will the international expansion be halted?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we're going to put a pause on our international expansion post the U.K. and Ireland 'till get back to global profitability. So that depends on how fast we can grow our global subscriber base, which will be some number of quarters. And we're eager to
componenttext: Well, we're going to put a pause on our international expansion post the U.K. and Ireland 'till get back to global profitability. So that depends on how fast we can grow our global subscriber base, which will be some number of quarters. And we're eager to get back to continuing the international expansion because we see it as such a large opportunity. But we need to take a few quarters to get our subscriber base back to the appropriate size.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Why did you choose the U.K. and Ireland as your next market, even though it's expensive on a relative basis, and are already fairly competitive? Hasn't Sky locked up most of the content rights already? What is your point of differentiation there?
componenttext: Why did you choose the U.K. and Ireland as your next market, even though it's expensive on a relative basis, and are already fairly competitive? Hasn't Sky locked up most of the content rights already? What is your point of differentiation there?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Sky Movies does have the fixed major studios, but there is a wide range of other movie content available from the non-fixed majors, and then there's a tremendous amount of television that's available also. And Sky Movies is expensive at GBP 16, or a
componenttext: Well, Sky Movies does have the fixed major studios, but there is a wide range of other movie content available from the non-fixed majors, and then there's a tremendous amount of television that's available also. And Sky Movies is expensive at GBP 16, or about $25 a month, and it's only taken now by less than 5 million citizens or households. So there's a big opportunity for those who don't have Sky Movies. And then for those who do have Sky Movies for using iTV content selection to attract those subscribers. So the answer to the question of why the U.K. and Ireland, it's because we see a very attractive market, with great, over-the-top penetration. Many consumers are very comfortable with online video, and use it frequently from 4 on Demand, from BBC iPlayer, Sky Go, all the different providers. So it's a very fertile market in that way. And our big advantage is really knowing streaming technology well, streaming marketing, and we feel great about entering with all of our CE partners.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: On international, you're now investing in multiple markets, when your core domestic market is experiencing growing pains. With U.K. and Ireland, you're entering into a market where LOVEFiLM was were the first mover. Can you discuss how you think about the
componenttext: On international, you're now investing in multiple markets, when your core domestic market is experiencing growing pains. With U.K. and Ireland, you're entering into a market where LOVEFiLM was were the first mover. Can you discuss how you think about the trade-off between establishing a foothold in international markets, while attempting to grow domestically through broadening the content library?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, in the U.S., we're very confident of our success in streaming. Our content is in the best shape it's ever been. It's really an incredible selection of content, and that's showing up for us in viewing hours and all the kind of key metrics. In Canada,
componenttext: Well, in the U.S., we're very confident of our success in streaming. Our content is in the best shape it's ever been. It's really an incredible selection of content, and that's showing up for us in viewing hours and all the kind of key metrics. In Canada, we're very successful, so we're excited about that. And now, we're going to be focusing on the U.K. And LOVEFiLM, which is owned by Amazon, is a well-run firm, they'll be a great competitor, they'll be one of a dozen competitors for over-the-top, including, as I mentioned, the BBC iPlayer, 4 on Demand, Sky Go and others. So it's -- we look forward to entering in the market and establishing what a great value Netflix is.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would also add that LOVEFiLm was the first mover in DVD-by-mail in the U.K, it's not clear to me that they're there the first mover in streaming. They do have some offering and they're increasing that offering. But if we launch in Q1, it's not clear tha
componenttext: I would also add that LOVEFiLm was the first mover in DVD-by-mail in the U.K, it's not clear to me that they're there the first mover in streaming. They do have some offering and they're increasing that offering. But if we launch in Q1, it's not clear that they're the first mover in streaming.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you quantify the magnitude of consolidated losses that you are likely to incur in the first part of 2012, as you launch in U.K. and Ireland?
componenttext: Can you quantify the magnitude of consolidated losses that you are likely to incur in the first part of 2012, as you launch in U.K. and Ireland?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, what we've said in Q4, we guided to contribution profit midpoint of $65 million loss. If you put that together with our statements that Canada is roughly breakeven, then you can assume that most of that is Latin American loss, plus some expenses rel
componenttext: Well, what we've said in Q4, we guided to contribution profit midpoint of $65 million loss. If you put that together with our statements that Canada is roughly breakeven, then you can assume that most of that is Latin American loss, plus some expenses related to prepping for the U.K. And I would say that the first quarter loss for the U.K. is, in rough numbers, akin to the Latin American loss.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: In positing your guidance, are you saying that Netflix will be unprofitable on a global basis over all of 2012? In other words, were losses over the next few quarters be larger than any profits that could come in 3Q or 4Q of 2012?
componenttext: In positing your guidance, are you saying that Netflix will be unprofitable on a global basis over all of 2012? In other words, were losses over the next few quarters be larger than any profits that could come in 3Q or 4Q of 2012?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: What we said is, that in the past few quarters, we're putting a pause on international until they get back to global profitability, and we haven't guided to the later half of 2012.
componenttext: What we said is, that in the past few quarters, we're putting a pause on international until they get back to global profitability, and we haven't guided to the later half of 2012.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Are any differences in terms of the types of content that are working in Latin America versus the U.S. and Canada? What types of shows and films are proving the most popular in there?
componenttext: Are any differences in terms of the types of content that are working in Latin America versus the U.S. and Canada? What types of shows and films are proving the most popular in there?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're very early in on Latin America, about 45 days since we launched. So we're just starting to learn those lessons, and to figure out how to constantly improve our service, as we did when we launched Canada, and then 6 months after we started Canada. So
componenttext: We're very early in on Latin America, about 45 days since we launched. So we're just starting to learn those lessons, and to figure out how to constantly improve our service, as we did when we launched Canada, and then 6 months after we started Canada. So we'll learn more every quarter on that.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: An easy anecdote on that one is telenovelas work well in Latin America, and they don't work in Canada. But I don't think that's telling you anything other than what Reed said.
componenttext: An easy anecdote on that one is telenovelas work well in Latin America, and they don't work in Canada. But I don't think that's telling you anything other than what Reed said.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you provide any more detail on your Latin American rollout? Which specific countries in Latin America has been the biggest contributors to your international subscriber growth?
componenttext: Can you provide any more detail on your Latin American rollout? Which specific countries in Latin America has been the biggest contributors to your international subscriber growth?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as you would expect, Mexico and Brazil are the 2 largest broadband streaming markets, and those are our 2 largest markets.
componenttext: Well, as you would expect, Mexico and Brazil are the 2 largest broadband streaming markets, and those are our 2 largest markets.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Moving on to a question about CE devices. In January at the CES conference, you announced that Best Buy, Memorex, Panasonic, Samsung, Sharp and others would add Netflix buttons to their remote controls to their devices. Can you give us an update on these
componenttext: Moving on to a question about CE devices. In January at the CES conference, you announced that Best Buy, Memorex, Panasonic, Samsung, Sharp and others would add Netflix buttons to their remote controls to their devices. Can you give us an update on these partnerships? With these devices they should be in time for the 2011 winter holiday season.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't know specifically on specific brands, but on as a whole, I would say the Netflix button program has been going great and there will be lots of devices in the market in Q4 in preparation for Christmas.
componenttext: I don't know specifically on specific brands, but on as a whole, I would say the Netflix button program has been going great and there will be lots of devices in the market in Q4 in preparation for Christmas.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: So on other miscellaneous questions. What is the company's guidance for its future tax rate? I can take this one. We guide to roughly 30% effective tax rate for the full year, and probably slightly higher, something around 38% for Q4, likely trending to s
componenttext: So on other miscellaneous questions. What is the company's guidance for its future tax rate? I can take this one. We guide to roughly 30% effective tax rate for the full year, and probably slightly higher, something around 38% for Q4, likely trending to say, 39% in the following year. If you look at the Q3 effective tax rate, it was quite low at approximately 33%, and that was due to the expiration of some statutory limitations on some past audits. So we have to treat that as ending Q3 that we won't have in future quarters.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just a clarification, Ellie, you said 37% for the full year, correct? Okay.
componenttext: And just a clarification, Ellie, you said 37% for the full year, correct? Okay.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. How long will you wait for regulatory clarity in the U.S. related to the Facebook issue?
componenttext: Yes. How long will you wait for regulatory clarity in the U.S. related to the Facebook issue?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a bill in Congress now, H.R. 2471, which clarifies that a consumer does have the right to get permission for their video data that we shared, and that predicting what the U.S. Congress is going to is not something we're going to engage in. I
componenttext: Well, there's a bill in Congress now, H.R. 2471, which clarifies that a consumer does have the right to get permission for their video data that we shared, and that predicting what the U.S. Congress is going to is not something we're going to engage in. If it passes, that's great, and fantastic for consumers everywhere. If it doesn't, we'll figure out our next step -- steps at that point.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. So at this time, I'd like to turn it over to the operator and begin taking live, call-in questions.
componenttext: Great. So at this time, I'd like to turn it over to the operator and begin taking live, call-in questions.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Youssef Squali from Jefferies and Company.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Youssef Squali from Jefferies and Company.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Reed, just a couple of question or really, one question going back to the DVD business. Clearly, it's -- as it starts atrophying, I'm just trying to understand what is the value of that business to you now outside of just being a cash cow? Are there any s
componenttext: Reed, just a couple of question or really, one question going back to the DVD business. Clearly, it's -- as it starts atrophying, I'm just trying to understand what is the value of that business to you now outside of just being a cash cow? Are there any synergies that still exist between that and the streaming business? And if there is any value to actually keep it under the same umbrella?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Youssef, at this point, it's a source of profits funding our international expansion, and it's a source of satisfaction to the more than 10 million members who subscribe to our DVD service, whether they also subscribe to streaming or not. And so we'll kee
componenttext: Youssef, at this point, it's a source of profits funding our international expansion, and it's a source of satisfaction to the more than 10 million members who subscribe to our DVD service, whether they also subscribe to streaming or not. And so we'll keep it and run it steadily, and keep the service while it's great for it. So that would be the plan going forward.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from... [Operator Instructions]
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from... [Operator Instructions]

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, that's okay you guys. Our job as we see, it is try to anticipate your questions and answer as many of them proactively in our investor letter as possible. I'll take the absence of telephone questions that, at least in that dimension, we're doing a g
componenttext: Well, that's okay you guys. Our job as we see, it is try to anticipate your questions and answer as many of them proactively in our investor letter as possible. I'll take the absence of telephone questions that, at least in that dimension, we're doing a good job. And I want to thank everyone for their support. We know it's been an extremely challenging time to be a shareholder over the last couple of months. And I want to tell everyone that we are extremely focused on growing our streaming business on a global basis, and believe it's a tremendous opportunity to create a very valuable and important and respected firm, and that's what everyday here at Netflix is spent doing. So with that, thank you all very much.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thanks for participating in today's program. This concludes the programming. You may all disconnect.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thanks for participating in today's program. This concludes the programming. You may all disconnect.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Netflix Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Q&A session. Today's call is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Ms. Ellie Mertz, VP of Finance and Investor
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Netflix Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Q&A session. Today's call is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Ms. Ellie Mertz, VP of Finance and Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Q&A session. I am joined here by Reed Hastings, CEO; and David Wells, CFO. We announced our financial results for the third quarter at approximately 1:25 p.m, Pacific Time
componenttext:
Thank you and good afternoon. Welcome to the Netflix Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Q&A session. I am joined here by Reed Hastings, CEO; and David Wells, CFO. 
We announced our financial results for the third quarter at approximately 1:25 p.m, Pacific Time today. The shareholder letter and the Q3 financial results and the webcast of this Q&A session are all available at the company's Investor Relations website at ir.netflix.com. As is our standard practice, we will begin the call with questions received via e-mail. Please e-mail your questions to ir@netflix.com. In the time remaining after e-mail Q&A, we will also open up the lines to take live, follow-up questions. The dial-in number is within our investor letter, but let me repeat it now. Please call (760) 666-3613 if you would like to get in the call queue. 
We may make forward-looking statements during this call regarding the company's future performance. Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to risks and uncertainties related to the business. A detailed discussion of such risks and uncertainties is contained in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the commission on February 18, 2011. A rebroadcast of this Q&A session will be available at the Netflix website after 6 p.m. Pacific Time today. 
Now let's move directly to questions. Similar to previous quarters, we have organized the questions by topic as we received them via e-mail this afternoon. We'll start with questions about the domestic business.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Given the sub losses in October, why are you so confident that November will be flat and December will have positive net adds for streaming? What does the churn look like week-to-week in October?
componenttext: Given the sub losses in October, why are you so confident that November will be flat and December will have positive net adds for streaming? What does the churn look like week-to-week in October?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Now, what we've seen is a second wave of cancellations from the price increase. The first wave was in July upon announcement, and the second wave has been in September and October, as people become more aware of the price increase, and then either changed
componenttext: Now, what we've seen is a second wave of cancellations from the price increase. The first wave was in July upon announcement, and the second wave has been in September and October, as people become more aware of the price increase, and then either changed the plan or canceled. And that wave has been declining very steadily over the past couple of weeks. And so we have substantially less weekly cancels now than we did just 3 to 4 weeks ago. So that's what gives us confidence that it's -- this wave passing through.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Why do you specifically believe your December month domestic net adds will be strongly positive? Do you plan a major marketing campaign to help make this happen?
componenttext: Why do you specifically believe your December month domestic net adds will be strongly positive? Do you plan a major marketing campaign to help make this happen?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our marketing has been very successful for the last several years, and we don't plan on any substantial change to it. It's a great set of campaigns that work very well at attracting streaming subscribers. And in Q4, particularly in December, there's more
componenttext: Our marketing has been very successful for the last several years, and we don't plan on any substantial change to it. It's a great set of campaigns that work very well at attracting streaming subscribers. And in Q4, particularly in December, there's more focus on a set of devices, video game consoles that get sold, iPads that get sold, a wide range of devices. And so our expectations are modeled from prior year's performance.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Why not reintroduce a combined streaming DVD plan offering at a discount for taking both?
componenttext: Why not reintroduce a combined streaming DVD plan offering at a discount for taking both?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as we addressed in the letter, we think the future is brightest by focusing on streaming. We could, in principle, offer discounts for hybrid, but if we were going to use discounting dollars, we wouldn't want to trying to incent more DVD use and subs
componenttext: Well, as we addressed in the letter, we think the future is brightest by focusing on streaming. We could, in principle, offer discounts for hybrid, but if we were going to use discounting dollars, we wouldn't want to trying to incent more DVD use and subsidizing DVDs, we'd want to be discounting streaming, and focus on getting even more market share. As it turns out, we think that $7.99 streaming is such a great price, that mostly we should focus on continuing to fill out the content. And so we're really quite comfortable in our growth with the 2 $7.99 programs.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Do you mean to ramp spending to win back sentiment, to drive a virtuous cycle, even if it means lower margins for the next 12 to 18 months? Has your programming spend targets for 2012 changed due to the change in subscriber trends? If so, what type of con
componenttext: Do you mean to ramp spending to win back sentiment, to drive a virtuous cycle, even if it means lower margins for the next 12 to 18 months? Has your programming spend targets for 2012 changed due to the change in subscriber trends? If so, what type of content are you giving up?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as we said in the letter, the focus for us is in building back our reputation and brand strength. But that's not through grand gestures, signing some crazy content deal or doing something else. It's the same set of steps that we've been using year a
componenttext: Well, as we said in the letter, the focus for us is in building back our reputation and brand strength. But that's not through grand gestures, signing some crazy content deal or doing something else. It's the same set of steps that we've been using year after year for the past 10 years in terms of building our brand, which is a steady focus on execution, improving our service quarter-after-quarter. And in terms of our programming content, we do have built into our plan substantial increases in the content investment over this year and over the prior year. It's really exciting that we're able to fill out that content as we documented in its effect in our letter.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you please provide apples-to-apples comparisons for your subscriber guidance? What does it imply on a unique subscriber basis? And how many hybrid subscribers are you assuming for Q4?
componenttext: Can you please provide apples-to-apples comparisons for your subscriber guidance? What does it imply on a unique subscriber basis? And how many hybrid subscribers are you assuming for Q4?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is David Wells, the CFO. So in terms of our subscriber guidance, what we said in the letter is we will be up slightly from the 23.8 million unique subscribers we needed Q3 with. So that tells you sort of where we are from a unique subscriber basis.
componenttext:
This is David Wells, the CFO. So in terms of our subscriber guidance, what we said in the letter is we will be up slightly from the 23.8 million unique subscribers we needed Q3 with. So that tells you sort of where we are from a unique subscriber basis. 
I will say that from a hybrid subscriber basis, we expect streaming only subscribers to grow substantially, DVD only subscribers to be up somewhat, and for those subscribers taking both services to be down. And I think all the pieces are there in the letter and the guidance.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Would churn peak in Q4?
componenttext: Would churn peak in Q4?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Really, we focus on net adds and growing the business. And we make it very easy for customers to exit or cancel Netflix and then come back. So we really don't focus on churn. We focus on total growth with the business or net additions.
componenttext: Really, we focus on net adds and growing the business. And we make it very easy for customers to exit or cancel Netflix and then come back. So we really don't focus on churn. We focus on total growth with the business or net additions.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I think if they were meaning to ask the question of, will the number of people leaving the service related to the price changes, peak end Q4, Reeds already answered that question in terms of the weekly trends that we see, and retention rates.
componenttext: And I think if they were meaning to ask the question of, will the number of people leaving the service related to the price changes, peak end Q4, Reeds already answered that question in terms of the weekly trends that we see, and retention rates.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you provide more detail about around your domestic streaming contribution margins? 8% seems unusually low, given that you already have 21 million streaming subscribers, and should therefore have significant scale. Is there a subscriber level at which
componenttext: Can you provide more detail about around your domestic streaming contribution margins? 8% seems unusually low, given that you already have 21 million streaming subscribers, and should therefore have significant scale. Is there a subscriber level at which you believe your streaming contribution margin will meet or exceed your DVD contribution margin?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think in the long-run, the long-term margin structure for streaming will be ultimately determined by the competitive space, and how many competitors we have. In the short run, we've been aggressively adding streaming content at the same rate of subscrib
componenttext: I think in the long-run, the long-term margin structure for streaming will be ultimately determined by the competitive space, and how many competitors we have. In the short run, we've been aggressively adding streaming content at the same rate of subscriber growth, and we continue to anticipate investing in that in 2012. But we do have the confidence that we'll be able to grow in pace along with that rate of investment addition. So we think we'll be able to take up contribution margin at the same time.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Related question. How will U.S. content cost double in 2012, and contribution margin be up 100 basis points over the quarter?
componenttext: Related question. How will U.S. content cost double in 2012, and contribution margin be up 100 basis points over the quarter?

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think I just answered that question, but we would anticipate that the growth of streaming subscribers to outpace the content addition.
componenttext: I think I just answered that question, but we would anticipate that the growth of streaming subscribers to outpace the content addition.

headline: Netflix, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, in the other part is that in Q4 of this year, we've taken the content cost way up. So it's not doubling the Q4 levels going forward, it's on a year-over-year basis.
